choices.text: Amoxicillin – clavulanic acid

questions.text: Which of the following antimicrobials is effective against an organism producing extended-spectrum beta-lactamases?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Piperacillin – tazobactam

  • ESBL is produced by gram-negative organisms like Klebsiella and E. coli.
  • They are resistant to most of the Beta-lactam antibiotics like Penicillins and most of the Cephalosporins.
  • Tazobactam, Sulbactam and Clavulanic acid are beta lactamase inhibitors, hence they can be used against ESBL producing organisms.
  • Therefore, the correct option will be Piperacillin + Tazobactam combination.

questions.text: A couple recently visited a family therapist for guidance on adapting to new changes in their life. They shared that they have just welcomed their first child into their household. Based on this life event, the therapist categorizes their family's current developmental stage. Which of the following best describes the phase that this family is entering according to the standard family life cycle theory?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Expansion/Extension

  • The family life cycle describes the emotional and developmental stages that most families go through.
  • These stages help professionals understand family dynamics and the evolution of family structures over time.
  • Family Cycle has SIX phases; each phase begins with the following events as described below.
    • Formation: Marriage of the husband and wife till Birth of the first child
    • Extension: Birth of the first child till Birth of the last child
    • Complete extension: Birth of the last child till First child moving out of the home 
    • Contraction: First child moving out of the home of his/her parents till All the children moving out
    • Complete Contraction: All the children moving out of their parents’ home till Death of one parent.
    • Dissolution: Death of one parent till Death of the other spouse (Extinction)

questions.text: A 28-year-old male with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department after experiencing a syncope episode. He reports a family history of sudden cardiac death. An ECG performed in the emergency department shows ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V3 with a right bundle branch block pattern but no ischemic changes. His electrolytes, including potassium and magnesium levels, are normal, and there is no evidence of structural heart disease on echocardiography. Considering the patient's history, ECG findings, and clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Brugada Syndrome

  • Brugada Syndrome is a genetic disorder that causes a characteristic ECG pattern of pseudo-right bundle branch block and ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V3, as seen in this patient.
  • It is associated with an increased risk of sudden cardiac death, especially in young patients with a family history of such events.
  • The absence of electrolyte disturbances and structural heart disease, along with the specific ECG changes, make Brugada Syndrome the most likely diagnosis.
  • Acute myocardial infarction usually presents with different ECG changes and symptoms.
  • Hyperkalemia typically shows different ECG alterations, such as peaked T waves.
  • Right ventricular dysplasia is a structural abnormality that would be detected on imaging, which was not observed in this case.

questions.text: An elderly male with dragging sensation in abdomen presents in the OPD. His cell count had elevated total leucocyte count and increased platelet count. His peripheral smear shows metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophilia and basophilia (image given for reference). Which of the following is the likely genetic anomaly present in this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. t (9; 22)

  • The increased cell count (leucocytes and platelets) with peripheral smear showing metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophilia and basophilia (mixed myeloid lineage) is suggestive of a diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia.
  • Two other features:
  • Age of the patient (peak incidence in 5/6th decade of life)
  • The dragging sensation (can be due to splenomegaly seen in CML patients) also fits in the diagnosis.

 

 

Ref: Robbins, 10th edition, page no. 622

questions.text: An employee who has been diagnosed with tuberculosis is eligible for an extended sickness benefit for:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2 years

 

Extended sickness benefit is given for a period of 2 years.

choices.text: The elevated CEA level is a definitive indicator of metastasis in colon cancer.
CEA levels are only useful for screening purposes in patients with a family history of colorectal cancer.
Elevated CEA levels can be useful in monitoring treatment response and recurrence in colorectal cancer.
The elevation in CEA is likely due to her smoking history and not related to her colon cancer.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female with a history of smoking and alcohol use presents to the clinic with a recent onset of abdominal pain and unexplained weight loss. She has no family history of cancer. An abdominal CT scan shows a suspicious mass in the colon, and a biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma. Her blood tests reveal an elevated Carcino-embryonic Antigen (CEA) level. Considering the patient's diagnosis and elevated CEA levels, which of the following statements is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Elevated CEA levels can be useful in monitoring treatment response and recurrence in colorectal cancer.

  • Carcino-embryonic Antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker that is frequently elevated in colorectal cancer.
  • While it is not used for screening or diagnostic purposes due to its lack of specificity, it can be valuable in monitoring treatment response and detecting recurrence after surgery in colorectal cancer patients.
  • Elevated CEA levels can be influenced by smoking, but in the context of a confirmed adenocarcinoma, the elevation is more likely related to her cancer.

choices.text: Cessation of smoking
Microlaryngeal surgery for biopsy

questions.text: A middle-aged male comes to the outpatient department (OPD) with the only complaint of hoarseness of voice for the past 2 years. He has been a chronic smoker for 30 years. On examination, a reddish area of mucosal irregularity overlying a portion of both cords was seen. Management would include all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bilateral cordectomy

  • In managing a middle-aged male with a long history of smoking and chronic hoarseness of voice, accompanied by observable mucosal irregularities on the vocal cords, several management strategies should be considered.

Analysis of given options:

 

Option A. Cessation of Smoking.

  • Smoking is a significant risk factor for laryngeal pathologies, including cancer. Chronic exposure to tobacco smoke can lead to changes in the vocal cord mucosa.
  • Advising the patient to stop smoking is a critical part of management. It can potentially improve the current symptoms and more importantly, reduce the risk of further damage and potential malignancy.
  • This option is a necessary and appropriate part of the management plan.

Option B. Bilateral Cordectomy.

  • Bilateral cordectomy, the surgical removal of both vocal cords, is a treatment usually reserved for bilateral vocal cord cancer.
  • It is a drastic measure and significantly impacts the patient's ability to speak. This procedure would only be considered if there were definitive evidence of bilateral cancer, and other treatment options were not viable.
  • Given the current information, without a confirmed diagnosis of bilateral cancer, this option seems premature and excessively invasive. A biopsy would be needed before considering such an extensive procedure.

Option C. Microlaryngeal Surgery for Biopsy.

  • Due to the chronic nature of the hoarseness and visible mucosal irregularities, a biopsy is essential to rule out cancer.
  • Microlaryngeal surgery would allow for a detailed examination of the larynx and vocal cords, and a biopsy can be taken for histopathological examination.
  • This option is a necessary part of the diagnostic process.

Option D. Regular Follow-up.

  • Regular follow-up is important to monitor the progression or resolution of the patient’s symptoms and to evaluate the effectiveness of any interventions.
  • Follow-up appointments are essential, especially if there is a need to monitor for potential complications or the development of malignancy.
  • This option is a recommended part of ongoing management.

Based on this analysis, the option that does NOT fit as part of the initial management plan for this patient is b. Bilateral Cordectomy, as it is an invasive treatment that should only be considered after a confirmed diagnosis and when less invasive treatment options are not suitable.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Identify appropriate management strategies for a patient presenting with chronic hoarseness and mucosal irregularities on the vocal cords, focusing on smoking cessation, diagnostic biopsy, and the importance of regular follow-up, while recognizing that invasive procedures like bilateral cordectomy require careful consideration and definitive diagnostic justification.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient arrives at the hospital emergency department presenting with gastrointestinal distress. The patient complains of severe abdominal pain, frequent vomiting, and watery diarrhea. During the physical examination, the medical team observes that the patient's stools emit an unusual faint glow. The patient appears disoriented and fatigued. The medical history reveals that the patient attended a local festival the previous day and consumed various food items there. The following exposures might be contributing to which substance toxication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Phosphorus

  • The vomitus and stools turn luminescent in acute phosphorus poisoning.
  • The stools also release mild fumes and this is called ‘smoky stool syndrome’.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Mercury. Acute mercury poisoning may cause headache, nausea, cough, chest pain, bronchitis, pulmonary edema, fine tremor, and CNS symptoms. Stools are bloody with shreds of mucous membrane but luminosity of vomitus and stools is not seen in mercury poisoning hence this choice is incorrect.

 

Option B. Cadmium. Poisoning characterized by sore throat, irritant cough, nausea, excessive salivation, metallic taste, headache and cyanosis (‘cadmium blues’) cramps in the abdomen, diarrhea, myalgia, bone pain, fractures with osteomalacia. Luminosity of vomitus and stools is not seen in cadmium poisoning hence this choice is incorrect.

 

Option D. Calcium. Symptoms of hypercalcemia includes Weakness, fatigue, Nausea, vomiting, Shortness of breath, Chest pain, Heart palpitations, irregular heart rate and constipation. Faint glow or luminescence of stools is not seen in calcium poisoning hence this choice is incorrect.

 

Key Learning objective:

 

PHOSPHORUS POISONING

  • Phosphorus exists in two varieties.

 

 

 

  • Oral and skin burns, luminescent ‘smoking’ vomitus and stools with a garlic odor, and GIT and biliary damage characterize white phosphorus poisoning.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a family history of renal cell carcinoma and cerebellar hemangioblastoma presents with complaints of visual disturbances and headaches. MRI of the brain reveals multiple cerebellar and spinal hemangioblastomas. Renal ultrasound shows bilateral renal cysts and a solid renal mass. Genetic testing is considered to confirm the diagnosis. Which gene is most likely to be mutated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. VHL gene

  • Von Hippel-Lindau disease is a hereditary cancer syndrome caused by mutations in the VHL gene.
  • This condition is associated with a variety of tumors and cysts, particularly in the central nervous system (like cerebellar and spinal hemangioblastomas) and kidneys (renal cell carcinoma and cysts).
  • The patient's family history and the presence of both cerebellar hemangioblastomas and renal abnormalities strongly suggest a diagnosis of von Hippel-Lindau disease.

Other options:

 

Option A. BRCA1 gene. Mutations in the BRCA1 gene are primarily associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers, not with the pattern of tumors seen in this patient.

 

Option B. TP53 gene. Mutations in TP53 are linked to Li-Fraumeni syndrome, which is characterized by a variety of cancers, including sarcomas, breast cancer, and brain tumors, but the specific combination of renal and cerebellar tumors is more typical of von Hippel-Lindau disease.

 

Option D. APC gene. APC gene mutations are associated with familial adenomatous polyposis, which primarily leads to colorectal cancer and does not typically present with the pattern of CNS and renal tumors seen in von Hippel-Lindau disease.

questions.text: The following patients are victims of a mass casualty. Assign appropriate triage codes to them.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

  • Triage means ‘to sort’. It aims at identifying patients who will benefit the most by being treated the earliest in case of mass casualties.
  • A four tier system is used for the same.

 

 

Ref: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no. 449

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman from a resource-limited setting presents to a local health camp with complaints of chronic eye irritation and a gritty feeling in her eyes for the past few months. On examination, conjunctival scarring and inward turning of the eyelashes are noted. The physician suspects trachoma and recalls the recommended WHO's SAFE strategy for managing trachoma in endemic areas. What does the "S" in the SAFE strategy stand for in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Surgery 

 

The SAFE Strategy for Trachoma:

 

S – Surgery (for correction of trachomatous trichiasis and entropion)

 

A – Antibiotic(Azithromycin)

 

F – Facial cleanliness to prevent disease transmission

 

E - Environmental change to increase access to water and sanitation.

 

TRACHOMA (ROUGH EYE) 

  • A microbial infection of the eye, caused due to the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • It is a contagious disease, that can be easily spread by direct contact with an affected person, by means of their eyes, eyelids, nasal and throat secretions and exchange of used towels and handkerchiefs. 
  • The risk factors of trachoma are poor sanitation, crowded living conditions and lack of routine hygiene practices due to poverty.
  • Moreover, trachoma commonly occurs in children between the ages of 2-5 years, more frequently in adult women than men and in surroundings where flies are rampant, as these can serve as vectors to transmit the bacteria.
  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of choice for Trachoma: Azithromycin 20 mg/kg oral stat
    • Current WHO recommendations for antibiotic treatment of trachoma:
      • District level prevalence is > 10% in 1-9 years old children: Mass treatment with Azithromycin
      • District level prevalence is 5-10% in 1-9 years old children: Targeted treatment with Azithromycin (the identification and treatment of all members of any family in whom one or more members have follicular trachoma)
      • District level prevalence is < 5% in 1-9 years old children: Azithromycin distribution may not be necessary
         
    • Mass treatment for Trachoma: [NEW GUIDELINES – WHO]
      • Indication of mass treatment in Trachoma: > 10% prevalence of severe and moderate Trachoma in children < 10 yrs of age [NEW GUIDELINES–WHO]
      • Treatment: 1% tetracycline ointment BD for 5 consecutive days each month or OD for 10 days each month for 6 consecutive months, or for 60 consecutive days
         
  • India was declared ‘Trachoma-Free’ in December 2017.

choices.text: Coccidioides immitis

questions.text: Which among the following dimorphic fungi produce Arthrospores at 25 C?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Coccidioides immitis

  • Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic fungus. Mode of infection is inhalation.
  • Arthrospores which are present in the dust are inhaled and it enters the lungs.
  • Body tissue/Culture at 37 C shows Spherules which are thick double layered wall filled inside with endospores.
  • Culture at 25C (Room temp) in blood agar shows colonies; these colonies when seen under microscope have Hyphae that looks fragmented giving rise to arthrospores (Barrel-shaped).

 

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No. 609

questions.text: Identify the causative agent:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Monkeypox

  • Monkey pox lesions evolve from macules (lesions with a flat base) to papules (raised firm painful lesions) to vesicles (filled with clear fluid) to pustules (filled with pus), followed by scabs or crusts.

Other options:

 

Option A. Herpes zoster. It affects a specific dermatome – hence, ruled out.

 

Option C. Chickenpox. Lesions will be pleomorphic – hence, ruled out.

 

Option D. Molluscum contagiosum. The lesions, known as Mollusca, are small, raised, and usually white, pink, or flesh-colored with a dimple or pit in the center – hence, ruled out.

 

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/health-topics/monkeypox#tab=tab_1

choices.text: Beta blockers

questions.text: A 64-year-old female with a past medical history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and congestive heart failure (CHF) presents with dyspnea at rest and with exertion, orthopnea, and lower extremity pitting edema. Her symptoms have worsened over the last 2 weeks. On examination, she is notably dyspneic and tachypneic, and also has jugular venous distension, 2+ pitting edema, and rales on lung examination. Patient is also found to have an audible S3. Her chest x-ray, pro-Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) level, and echocardiogram confirm the clinical suspicion of CHF exacerbation with pulmonary edema. She is already on maximal medical therapy with an ACE inhibitor, beta blocker, statins, and aspirin. She is appropriately placed on oxygen and given intravenous furosemide. Which of the following co-administered drugs can theoretically attenuate the diuretic effect of furosemide?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aspirin

  • Loop diuretics can induce the expression of COX-2 that results in the synthesis of prostaglandins from arachidonic acid.
  • PGE 2 inhibits salt transport in the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle and thus participates in the renal actions of loop diuretics.
  • NSAIDs (e.g., aspirin), which blunt cyclooxygenase activity, can interfere with the actions of loop diuretics by reducing prostaglandin synthesis in the kidney.
  • This interference is minimal in otherwise normal subjects but may be significant in patients with nephrotic syndrome or hepatic cirrhosis.
  • Loop agents have direct effects on blood flow through several vascular beds.
  • Furosemide increases renal blood flow via prostaglandin actions on kidney vasculature.
  • Both furosemide and ethacrynic acid have also been shown to reduce pulmonary congestion and left ventricular filling pressures in heart failure before a measurable increase in urinary output occurs.
  • These effects on peripheral vascular tone are also due to release of renal prostaglandins that were induced by the diuretics.

questions.text:
Dr. Arvind, a public health expert, was conducting a seminar on global initiatives for sustainable development. While discussing various organizations and their roles, he posed a question to the audience to gauge their understanding of the topic:

 

"In the context of worldwide initiatives, can you identify which organization is at the forefront in offering support for active sustainable development goals?"
questions.solution:
Ans. D. UNDP 

 

 

 

UNDP: UNITED NATIONS DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM

  • Headquarters; New York USA
  • The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) was established in 1966. It is the main source of funds for technical assistance. The member countries of the United Nations meet annually and pledge contributions to the UNDP.
  • The basic objective of the UNDP is to help poorer nations develop their human and natural resources more fully. The UNDP projects cover virtually every economic and social sector - agriculture, industry, education and science, health, social welfare, etc.
  • The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), also known as the Global Goals, were adopted by all United Nations Member States in 2015 as a universal call to action to end poverty, protect the planet and ensure that all people enjoy peace and prosperity by 2030.
  • UN’s Development arm, United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) has worked with the United Nations Development Group (UNDG) in developing a strategy for effective and coherent implementation support of the new sustainable development agenda under the acronym ‘MAPS’ (Mainstreaming, Acceleration, and Policy Support).

questions.text: Which of the following drug is used in CHF for relief of congestive symptoms and restoration of cardiac performance but does not possess inotropic action?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Metoprolol 

 

There are two distinct goals of drug therapy in CHF:

  1. Relief of congestive symptoms and restoration of cardiac performance: This can be achieved by:
  • Inotropic drugs: Digoxin, dobutamine, dopamine, amrinone, milrinone
  • Diuretics: Furosemide, thiazides
  • RAAS inhibitors: ACE inhibitors and ARBs
  • Vasodilators: Hydralazine, nitrates, nitroprusside
  • Beta blocker: Metoprolol, bisoprolol, carvediol, Nebivolol
  1. Reversal of disease progression and prolongation of survival: This is possible with:
  • ACE inhibitors and ARBs
  • Beta blockers: Metoprolol, bisoprolol, carvediol
  • Aldosterone antagonist: Spironolactone, eplerenone

questions.text: Which of the following diuretics is contraindicated in the presence of cardiac failure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mannitol

  • Mannitol is osmotic diuretic that expands plasma volume.
  • Therefore, it is contraindicated in any condition where we do not want to increase intravascular volume like cardiac failure (CHF) and pulmonary edema.
  • It is also contraindicated in acute tubular necrosis, anuria, and cerebral hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male reports to the outpatient clinic complaining of recurrent, intense episodes of fear characterized by palpitations, diaphoresis, a sense of impending doom, and shortness of breath. These episodes seem to occur spontaneously and have not been associated with any specific triggers. He has undergone a comprehensive workup including cardiac monitoring, blood tests, and a pulmonary function test, which have all returned normal results. Despite this, he has developed a persistent concern about the recurrence of these episodes, leading to significant lifestyle modifications. He has started avoiding leaving his home alone, fearing that he might experience an attack in public where help may not be available. Which of the following is not true for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hypochondriasis

  • The clinical presentation is typical of panic disorder with agoraphobia.

Option A. Panic attacks are characterized by intense, often unexpected, episodes of fear accompanied by physiological symptoms.

 

Option B. Anticipatory anxiety is the anxiety about having future panic attacks, which is evident in this patient's concern for recurrent episodes.

 

Option C. Agoraphobia is a fear of being in situations where escape might be difficult or help might not be available, leading to avoidance of these situations, as described by the patient's reluctance to leave home alone.

 

Option D. Hypochondriasis, now more commonly referred to as illness anxiety disorder, is characterized by excessive worry about having a serious illness, which does not match the patient's primary concern of experiencing recurrent panic attacks and therefore is not true for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Differentiate between panic disorder with agoraphobia and illness anxiety disorder.
  • Patients with panic disorder with agoraphobia fear the onset of panic attacks and may avoid situations due to this fear, whereas patients with illness anxiety disorder are preoccupied with having or acquiring a serious illness based on misinterpretation of bodily symptoms.

choices.text: Fatty metamorphosis of liver
Fatty degeneration of myocardium
Metaplasia of muscle to adipose tissue

questions.text: The lifestyle patterns of healthy persons from 20 to 30 years of age are studied. A subset of these persons has a lifestyle characterized by consumption of a lot of pizza and very little physical exercise. Which of the following tissue changes is most likely to develop in this subset of persons as a consequence of this lifestyle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypertrophy of steatocytes

  • The fat cells (adipocytes) increase in size (hypertrophy) with obesity in adults, and this is the predominant effect of weight gain.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Fatty metamorphosis of liver. Fatty change in the liver is due to toxic and metabolic derangements, such as those that occur with malnutrition or alcoholism.

 

Option B. Fatty degeneration of myocardium. Similarly, fatty change in the heart is a consequence of toxic or hypoxic events.

 

Option D. Metaplasia of muscle to adipose tissue. Muscle does not typically undergo metaplasia in response to weight gain. Adipocytes in fascial planes and around the muscle can increase in size. The muscle may atrophy in response to the sedentary lifestyle.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A resident is doing tubal ligation for the 1st time. She is unsure which part of the tube she needs to ligate. Which part of the tube is ligated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Isthmus

  • As per Government of India guidelines, in Pomeroy’s technique, the tube is ligated at the isthmic area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

POMEROY’S GUIDELINES (GOI GUIDELINES)

  • The operating surgeon should identify each fallopian tube clearly, following it right up to the fimbria.
  • The site of the occlusion of the fallopian tube must always be within 2-3 cm from the uterine cornua in the isthmal portion (this will improve the possibility of reversal if required in the future).
  • Care must be taken to avoid damage to the blood vessels, ovaries, and surrounding tissues.
  • Excision of 1 cm of the tube should be done. Use of cautery and crushing of the tube should be avoided.
  • A loop is made using a Babcock’s forceps and ligated with catgut.
  • A 1 cm loop is then cut.
  • The same is repeated on the other side.

 

Ref: https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/guidelines/nrhm-guidelines/family-planning/std-for-sterilization-services.pdf

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency room with rapid heartbeat and palpitations. On examination, he is tachycardic with an irregular pulse and exhibits agitation and paranoia. Notably, there are fresh superficial scratch marks across his arms. He admits to recent drug use but does not specify which substances. Which of the following substances is most likely to be responsible for this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cocaine

  • Cocaine is a central nervous system stimulant known to cause increased sympathetic activity leading to tachycardia, arrhythmias, and hyperactivity.
  • Cocaine users can experience formication, the sensation of bugs crawling under the skin, which can lead to scratching and excoriations.
  • The patient's presentation is consistent with the effects of cocaine intoxication.

Incorrect Options:

 

Option B. Heroin is an opioid that generally causes bradycardia (slowed heart rate) and respiratory depression. Scratching can occur due to histamine release, but it is not commonly associated with arrhythmias.

 

Option C. Cannabis typically produces tachycardia immediately after use but is not known to cause arrhythmias. The drug's effects usually include euphoria, relaxation, and altered sensory perception rather than agitation and paranoia.

 

Option D. Alcohol intoxication can cause tachycardia but is less likely to cause arrhythmias unless there is underlying pathology or chronic misuse leading to cardiomyopathy. Scratch marks are not a typical presentation of alcohol intoxication.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Recognize the signs and symptoms of cocaine intoxication, which include tachycardia, arrhythmias, and formication leading to skin excoriations, in addition to behavioral changes such as agitation and paranoia.

choices.text: Typical Subtrochanteric Fracture
Paget’s Disease of Bone
Malignancy of the bone

questions.text: A 57-year-old female with severe Inflammatory Arthritis and on long term medications for treatment of Osteoporosis suddenly presented in emergency with pain in thigh with Inability to ambulate. X-Rays were performed as below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Atypical Fracture

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option A. Atypical Fracture. The X-ray shows features of an atypical femoral fracture. Atypical fractures of the femur are associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates, which are commonly prescribed for the treatment of osteoporosis. These fractures typically occur in the subtrochanteric or diaphyseal region of the femur and have distinct radiographic features, including transverse or short oblique patterns with medial cortical thickening and lateral cortical beaking. The patient's clinical history of osteoporosis medication use and the location and appearance of the fracture are consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Typical Subtrochanteric Fracture. This option is not supported by the X-ray findings, as the fracture does not appear to be a typical subtrochanteric fracture. Typical subtrochanteric fractures are often associated with trauma or osteoporosis but do not exhibit the atypical features seen in this X-ray.

 

Option C. Paget's Disease of Bone. Paget's disease of bone can cause bone deformities and fractures, but the X-ray findings do not show the characteristic appearance of Paget's disease, which includes areas of increased bone density and disorganized bone structure.

 

Option D. Malignancy of the Bone. While malignancies can lead to pathological fractures, the X-ray findings do not show the typical features of bone malignancies, such as destructive bone lesions or soft tissue masses.

choices.text: Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days.
Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days.
Right umbilical vein is absent.
Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks.

questions.text: The false statement about fetal circulation is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days.

  • The anatomical closure of the foramen ovale takes 1 month to a year.

 

Let's discuss each option in detail:

 

Option A. Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days.

  • The foramen ovale is an opening in the interatrial septum that allows blood to flow directly from the right atrium to the left atrium, bypassing the lungs. After birth, as the baby begins to breathe and the lungs expand, the pressure in the left atrium increases relative to the right atrium, causing the flap-like valve of the foramen ovale to close.
  • Functional closure, where the valve is pressed shut due to the pressure difference between the atria, usually occurs immediately after birth. Anatomical closure, where the tissue actually grows together and seals the foramen, typically occurs within the first year of life, but not as quickly as 3 to 5 days. Hence, this statement is false.

Option B. Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days.

  • The ductus venosus connects the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava, allowing oxygenated blood from the placenta to bypass the liver and flow directly to the heart.
  • After birth, the ductus venosus constricts and eventually closes, typically within a few days to a week. It becomes a fibrous cord known as the ligamentum venosum.

Option C. Right umbilical vein is absent.

  • In fetal circulation, there are two umbilical arteries and one umbilical vein.
  • The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.
  • It's noteworthy that only the left umbilical vein persists, while the right one regresses early in development.
  • Hence, this statement is accurate.

Option D. Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks.

  • The ductus arteriosus is a vessel that connects the pulmonary artery to the descending aorta. It allows blood to bypass the fetal lungs, which are not yet functional for breathing.
  • After birth, increased oxygen concentration and decreased levels of certain prostaglandins cause the ductus arteriosus to constrict. Functional closure usually happens within the first couple of days after birth, and it undergoes anatomical closure (becoming the ligamentum arteriosum) typically within the first few weeks to months of life.

choices.text: National Board of Examinations (NBE)
National Institute of Health & Family Welfare (NIHFW)
Medical Council of India (MCI)
National Planning Commission (NPC)

questions.text: A political science postgraduate student at Jawaharlal Nehru University in New Delhi is preparing for a presentation on the evolution of planning bodies in India. As he delves into recent developments, he recalls that a renowned institution, which played a pivotal role in India's developmental planning for decades, was replaced by a new institution called NITI Aayog. Which of the following institutions was superseded by the formation of NITI Aayog?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. National Planning Commission (NPC)

  • NITI Aayog (National Institution for Transforming India Aayog) was established by the Prime Minister after dissolving the National Planning Commission in 1st of January 2015.
  • The Prime Minister is the Chairperson and the headquarters are in New Delhi.

Other Options:

questions.text: A 42-year-old male was admitted in the medicine ward with a history of severe abdominal pain associated with vomiting, loss of weight and loss of appetite. He was found to have increased levels of gastrin in his blood and on further evaluation, he was diagnosed to have gastrinoma. Overlapping actions can be seen between gastrin and which of these hormones in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cholecystokinin

  • The hormone gastrin will act through the receptors CCK-B, which are related to the primary cholecystokinin receptors CCK-A and this explains the structural similarity between these two hormones.
  • Because of this, there may be overlapping effects, if there are excess quantities of these two hormones (or one of them).
  • Gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome) is a gastrin secreting tumor, so overlapping actions can be seen with cholecystokinin (CCK).

 

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th edition, page no. 468

choices.text: LJ media
CHROM agar
CLED agar
Mac Conkey agar

questions.text: Identify the media that is given in the following image which acts as a differential and indicator media in urine samples:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. CLED agar

 

DIFFERENTIAL MEDIA

  • It differentiates between two groups of bacteria by using an indicator, which changes the colour of the colonies of a particular group of bacteria but not the other group.
  • It is mainly helpful in urine and stool samples to differentiate lactose fermenting and non-lactose fermenting colonies.
  • E.g., MacConkey agar, CLED agar
  • The given image is CLED agar, which is greenish blue in colour, whereas MacConkey agar looks pinkish in colour.
  • CLED stands for cysteine-lactose-electrolyte-deficient agar. Its Indicator is Bromothymol blue.
  • In MacConkey Agar, the indicator is Neutral red. Its constituents are:

P – Peptone

L – Lactose

A – Agar

N – Neutral Red (Indicator)

T – Taurocholate

  • CLED agar is preferred over MacConkey agar. It promotes the growth of urinary pathogens, Candida and S. aureus.

Other options:

 

Option A. LJ media is seen in slopes and green in colour. It is a selective medium for the growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Option B. CHROM agar is a chromogenic medium that is used for the speciation of the Candida species. Each species produces different coloured colonies.

 

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Chapter 2, Page No. 29

questions.text: The gold standard for the diagnosis of fetal infection with CMV is:

  • The investigation of choice (Gold standard) for fetal infection with CMV is CMV nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT).
  • However, Routine testing for CMV in pregnancy is not recommended.
  • If suspicion is there then, then amniotic fluid NAAT is done.

 

Educational Objective:

Ref: William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no. 1212

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the modified Duke's criteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is a major criterion.

  • Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is considered as one of the major criteria to establish the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.

 

 

a Typical, microorganism consistent with IE: HACEK group, viridans streptococci, streptococcus bovis, staphylococcus aureus; or community-acquired enterococci, or single positive blood cultures for Coxiella burnetii for antiphase I IgG antibody titre 11: 800.

b Oscillating endothelial, valvular vegetarian, abscess, pseudoaneurysm, intracardiac fistula, valvular perforation, or aneurysm, new (partial) dehiscence of prosthetic valve.

c Major arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infracts, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial haemorrhage, conjunctival haemorrhage and janeway’s lesion.

d Glomerulonephritis, Osler’s node, Roth’s spots and rheumatoid factor.

e Positive blood culture but not meeting the major criteria or serologic evidence of active infection with organisms with IE.

f Requires repeated/ extended (novel imaging techniques) diagnostic assessment to confirm or reject IE.

choices.text: Interferon gamma release assay
All of the above

questions.text: TB test done only on whole blood sample is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Interferon gamma release assay

  • TB test done on a whole blood sample is the interferon-gamma release assay.
  • It has been used for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis in patients with HIV (who frequently have a negative Mantoux test).
  • Interferon-gamma release assays include:
    • QuantiFERON-TB Gold
    • T-SPOT.TB
       
  • QuantiFERON-TB Gold quantitates the amount of IN- produced by CD4+ T cells in response to the antigens from Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus) is an improved version of the QuantiFERON-TB Gold test.
  • QuantiFERON-TB Gold detects only TB-specific CD4+ responses.
  • However, QuantiFeron-TB Gold Plus detects both CD8+ and CD4+ T-cell responses to TB-specific antigens.
  • T-SPOT.TB determines the total number of individual effector T cells expressing IFN-v.
  • The TrueNat TB test is a new molecular test that can diagnose TB in one hour as well as test for rifampicin resistance. This test uses a sputum sample taken from the patient. Only about 0.5 ml of the sample is required.
  • Gene Xpert is also a molecular method of testing that cannot use blood as a sample.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fatigue, chronic diarrhea, weight loss, bone pain, and abdominal distension. Investigations revealed iron deficiency anemia and osteoporosis. Which of the following is the single best test to be done for her evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody

  • History is suggestive of chronic diarrhea with malabsorption occurring at the proximal small intestine (duodenum+ jejunum) causing protein loss (ascites, weight loss diarrhea), Osteoporosis (calcium, magnesium), and Iron deficiency (anemia).
  • All above in a young patient should hint towards the possibility of celiac disease.

 

Ref: Harrison’s 21st edition, Celiac disease, Chapter 325

Hepatitis B has been a concern in certain pockets of our country. Given our national immunization schedule, tell me, when should we ideally give the first dose of the Hep B vaccine to a neonate?"

questions.text: Which among the following agents is helpful for inactivation of vaccines?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Beta propiolactone

  • Beta propiolactone (0.2%) is active against all the microorganisms including spores.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a painful and tender nodule on her shin. She reports a history of tuberculosis and was treated successfully. A biopsy of the lesion shows a granulomatous inflammation with giant cells. What type of giant cells is most likely present in her lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Langhans giant cells

  • Langhans giant cells are multinucleated cells with a horseshoe-shaped arrangement of nuclei that are typically present in granulomatous inflammation associated with tuberculosis.
  • These giant cells are formed by the fusion of epithelioid cells, which are activated macrophages that have taken up and processed the antigen.
  • The presence of Langhans giant cells is a characteristic feature of granulomatous inflammation associated with tuberculosis.

choices.text: Pigment stones can form due to biliary tract infections.
The most common type of bile stones in Asia are cholesterol stones.
Mirizzi syndrome is associated with jaundice.
