questions.text: A female patient with a BMI of 30kg/m2 came to the OPD with complaints of right upper quadrant pain since 7 days. She has history of consumption of OCPs. The following imaging was obtained. What is the incorrect statement with respect to the below condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The most common type of bile stones in Asia are cholesterol stones.

  • The most common type of bile stones in Asia are pigment stones.
  • Types of gallstones:
    1. Cholesterol stones/mixed type: MC type in western world – radiolucent
    2. Pigment stones: MC type in Asia – two types:
      • Brown pigment stone: due to worms/foreign body in CBD; radio opaque
      • Black pigment stones: due hemolytic anemia, also radio opaque

Other options:

 

Option C. Jaundice may ensue if the gallstone gets trapped in cystic duct, which gets inflammed and compresses the CHD (Mirizzi).

 

Option D. Occasionally, complete obstruction of the cystic duct leads to reabsorption of bile salts by the gallbladder epithelium and secretion of uninfected mucus, resulting in a mucocele of the gallbladder.

 

 

Ref: Bailey, 28th Edition, Page no. 1244

questions.text: The following is a victim of a firearm injury. What is the suspected distance of the shot?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intermediate range

  • In the image, around the firearm wound, only Tattooing is present.
  • There is no blackening or singeing.
  • This is characteristic of intermediate range.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Close Range. Burning, blackening and tattooing are present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent), but in the question only tattooing is present.

 

Option C. Point Blank. It refers to extremely close range, but not in contact. So, the features are similar to close range.

 

Option D. Distant Range. Neither of three features (singeing, blackening and tattooing) are present in distant range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ENTRY WOUND FEATURES

  • Contact (tight contact): Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  • Close Contact (Close Range contact/Point Blank/Loose contact/Near contact#): Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  • Intermediate Range/Near range#/Medium Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  • Distant range/Long Range: None of these present around the wound.

 

#Near Contact and Near range are different.

choices.text: Histidine load test
Dexa suppression test
Isovaleric acid levels
Aminoleuvelinic acid levels

questions.text: Folic acid deficiency can be estimated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Histidine load test

  • The histidine load test, also known as the FIGLU test, measures urinary excretion of formiminoglutamic acid (FIGlu) after a histidine load. 
  • The test is used to diagnose folate deficiency. 
  • During the test, a dose of the amino acid histidine is given by mouth. 
  • Histidine requires folate or vitamin B12 for its complete breakdown. 
  • In the absence of these vitamins, FIGlu, an intermediate product in histidine metabolism, accumulates and can be detected in the urine. 
  • High levels of FIGlu indicates: 
    • Insufficient folic acid
    • Increased alcohol consumption
    • Excessive consumption of processed foods

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presented with trismus, fever, swelling pushing the tonsils medially and spreading laterally posterior to the middle sternocleidomastoid. He gives H/O excision of 3rd molar few days back for dental caries. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Parapharyngeal abscess

  • The clinical presentation of a 33-year-old male with trismus (lockjaw), fever, swelling that pushes the tonsils medially and spreads laterally posterior to the middle sternocleidomastoid muscle, following the excision of a third molar for dental caries, can be indicative of a serious infection.

Analysis of given options:

 

Option A. Retropharyngeal Abscess.

  • A retropharyngeal abscess is an accumulation of pus in the retropharyngeal space, which lies behind the pharynx.
  • While it can cause fever and swelling, it is more commonly associated with difficulty swallowing and neck stiffness, rather than trismus and the specific pattern of swelling described.
  • It is less likely in adults and is more common in children.

 

Option B. Ludwig's Angina.

  • Ludwig's angina is a severe, rapidly spreading cellulitis, or bacterial infection, of the floor of the mouth, often occurring after tooth infection or extraction.
  • It presents with swelling of the neck, pain, trismus, and can progress to involve the submandibular, sublingual, and submental spaces.
  • However, the swelling typically doesn't extend posteriorly to the area behind the sternocleidomastoid muscle as described in the scenario.

 

Option C. Submental Abscess.

  • A submental abscess is a collection of pus in the submental space (under the chin).
  • Symptoms can include swelling in the submental area, pain, and possibly trismus.
  • This condition would not typically cause swelling that extends posteriorly behind the sternocleidomastoid muscle or medial displacement of the tonsils.

Option D. Parapharyngeal Abscess.

  • A parapharyngeal abscess is a deep neck infection in the parapharyngeal space, which is lateral to the pharynx.
  • This condition can present with trismus, fever, and swelling that may push the tonsils medially, consistent with the patient's symptoms.
  • The spread of infection to this area can occur following dental procedures, such as the excision of a molar.

Based on the details provided, the most likely diagnosis for this patient is D. Parapharyngeal Abscess. The presentation of medial displacement of the tonsils and swelling extending laterally posterior to the sternocleidomastoid, along with the history of recent dental surgery, aligns well with this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnose a parapharyngeal abscess by recognizing the clinical presentation of trismus, fever, and specific patterns of swelling in the context of recent dental procedures.

choices.text: Vimentin, epithelial membrane antigen, inhibin, CD99
Desmin, S-100 protein, smooth muscle antigen, cytokeratin

questions.text: Sections from a solid-cystic unilateral ovarian tumor in a 30-year-old female show a tumor composed of diffuse sheets of small cells with doubtful nuclear grooving and scanty cytoplasm. No Call-Exner bodies are seen.  The ideal immunohistochemistry panel would include:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vimentin, epithelial membrane antigen, inhibin, CD99

 

  • The specimen in the given question is most likely to be of granulosa cell tumor of ovary.
  • The features pointing toward this diagnosis are: 
    • Unilateral tumor
    • Solid and cystic areas
    • Small cells arranged in sheets
    • Nuclear grooving
    • Scant cytoplasm
  • The only point against this diagnosis is absence of Call-Exner bodies, but note that these structures if found are diagnostic of Granulosa cell tumors but these are not prerequisite for diagnosis.
  • Vimentin, EMA, inhibin and CD99 all are the markers of granulosa cell tumors.

 

Ideal IHC Panel:

 

  • Vimentin mesenchymal marker (positive)
  • Epithelial membrane antigen (EMA) usually negative in granulosa cell tumors; helps exclude epithelial tumors
  • Inhibin positive in sex cord-stromal tumors
  • CD99 variably positive in granulosa cell tumors
  • This panel is ideal to:
    • Confirm granulosa cell tumor
    • Rule out epithelial and lymphoid malignancies

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desmin, S-100, SMA, cytokeratin:

 

  • More useful in muscle tumors, neural tumors, or spindle cell neoplasms
  • Not ideal for diagnosing granulosa cell tumors

 

Option C. Chromogranin, CD45, CD99, CD20:

 

  • Markers for neuroendocrine tumors (chromogranin), lymphomas (CD45, CD20)
  • Not appropriate here

 

Option D. CD3, Chromogranin, CD45, Synaptophysin:

 

  • Markers for T-cell lymphoma and neuroendocrine tumors
  • Not applicable to ovarian sex cord-stromal tumors

choices.text: Kinked endotracheal tube
Airway obstruction or increased airway resistance
Equipment malfunction in the CO2 monitoring system

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient undergoes an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and smokes one pack of cigarettes daily. Anesthesia is induced without any complications, and the patient is intubated using a cuffed endotracheal tube. During the surgical procedure, you notice a change in the capnography waveform. Instead of a normal square waveform, there is a gradual upslope during the expiratory phase and a decreased end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) value. Based on the capnography findings, what is the most likely explanation for the observed changes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Airway obstruction or increased airway resistance

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option A.  Kinked endotracheal tube. A kinked endotracheal tube can lead to significant resistance in the airway, but it typically results in a complete blockage of the airway, causing a sudden and complete loss of CO2 waveform. The gradual upslope observed in this case is not consistent with a kinked tube.

 

Option B. Hyperventilation. Hyperventilation typically leads to a decrease in ETCO2 values, but it doesn't cause a gradual upslope during the expiratory phase. Instead, it results in a faster exhalation of CO2 and a steeper downslope of the waveform.

 

Option C.  Airway obstruction or increased airway resistance. This is the most likely explanation for the observed changes in the capnography waveform. Increased airway resistance or partial airway obstruction can cause a gradual upslope during the expiratory phase as the exhalation of CO2 is slowed down or impeded. This is often seen as a characteristic waveform change in conditions like bronchospasm or when there is a partial obstruction in the airway.

 

Option D. Equipment malfunction in the CO2 monitoring system. While equipment malfunction is a possibility, it's less likely in this case because the gradual upslope and decreased ETCO2 values are indicative of a physiological change in the patient's airway, such as increased resistance or partial obstruction. Equipment malfunction would typically result in an erratic or non-interpretable waveform rather than the specific changes described.

 

Educational objective:

  • Capnography is a medical monitoring technique that measures the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled breath. It has various applications in healthcare and emergency medicine.

 

 

 

Normal capnography waveform

  • Some of the abnormal capnography waveforms:
      1.  

            1. Mechanical airway obstruction:

 

 

 

      1.  

2. Cardiac oscillations:

 

 

 

  • This waveform represents the pulsation of an extra-large heart, transmitted to the lung parenchyma. The resulting changes in lung volume are enough to move a small amount of gas back and forth, creating "ventilation" of a sort. In some circumstances, this may be a feature of cardiomegaly.

 

3. The "Curare Cleft":

 

 

 

  • The "curare cleft" seen in the alveolar plateau is actually a patient making an attempt to breathe. With their feeble inspiratory effort, some fresh gas sucked from the ventilator tubing and past the capnometer, generating this pattern. It is most frequently seen in anaesthetic machines where there is a constant flow of fresh gas across the circuit.
      1.  

4. A low end-tidal CO2 in hypothermia:

 

 

 

  • In hypothermia, the total body CO2 production is greatly decreased (as the metabolic rate is decreased by 6% for every degree below 36°). The end-tidal CO2 in these people will be unnaturally low.
  • This can be seen in a number of other conditions. For instance, a low-cardiac-output state generates a low end-tidal CO2 because there is simply not enough flow across the pulmonary circulation. Or, alternatively, deep anaesthesia and muscle paralysis will result in a similar picture.

 

5. A high peak of the alveolar phase in poorly compliant lungs:

 

 

 

  • This pattern is called a "pigtail" capnogram. It is typically seen in poor lung compliance, but it can also occur in pregnant women and obese patients. Essentially, the sudden peak of pre-inspiratory expired CO2 is due to sudden airway closure. It occurs when a poorly compliant lung (or a huge fat chest wall, or a big pregnant belly) crushes the last few milliliters of CO2-rich gas from the alveoli before the collapse of the lung parenchyma also occludes the small bronchi and puts an end to the escape of gas.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman undergoes dilation and curettage for abnormal uterine bleeding. Identify this instrument used in the procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Uterine curette

  • This is an image of a uterine curette.
  • It is used for curetting the endometrium in the following procedures:
    • Dilatation and curettage
    • Following suction evacuation in MTP
  • It has a sharp end (used in gynae procedures) and a blunt end (used in obstetric procedures).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ovum forceps. This is used to evacuate products of conception and looks as shown below.

 

 

Option B. Punch biopsy forceps. This is used to take a biopsy from a cervical growth and looks like:

 

 

Option C. Tenaculum. This is a sharp single toothed instrument used to hold the cervix during any gyn procedure. It is used in place of a vulsullum. It is as shown below:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

  • A uterine curette is used for curetting the endometrium in the following procedures:
    • Dilatation and curettage
    • Following suction evacuation in MTP
  • It has a sharp end (used in gynae procedures) and a blunt end (used in obstetric procedures).

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition, Page no. 523

choices.text: Nissen fundoplication – gas bloat syndrome
Toupet fundoplication – gas bloat syndrome
Nissen fundoplication – short term dysphagia
Toupet fundoplication – short term dysphagia

questions.text: Identify the anti-reflux procedure in the image and its most common complication.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nissen fundoplication – short term dysphagia

  • The mechanism of Nissen fundoplication is to create a ‘floppy’ 360-degree wrap around the Gastro-esophageal junction and to restore the angle of His. It has the effect of increasing LOS basal pressure, lessening TLOSR and reducing the capacity of the gastric fundus, thereby enhancing gastric emptying.
  • Complete fundoplication (Nissen) is associated with a higher incidence of short-term dysphagia but is most durable in reflux control.
  • The most common side effect of fundoplication is short- term dysphagia, related presumably to tissue oedema and inflammation. It usually resolves within 3 months of surgery.
  • Some patients may experience ‘gas-bloat syndrome’, especially after a complete fundoplication. Typically, the patient would complain of gaseous distension of the abdomen and failure to belch or vomit, together with an increase in flatulence.
  • Toupet: Posterior 270° wrap
  • Dor: Anterior 180° wrap

 

 

Ref: Bailey, 28th edition, page no. 1116

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents for routine ultrasound at 28 weeks gestation. On examination, oligohydramnios was noted. A 4D USG reveals the findings of flattened nose, low-set ears, and limb deformities. The baby was delivered after a few weeks and the image of the baby is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the history and clinical features?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Potter’s syndrome

  • This is a rare congenital anomaly characterized by bilateral renal agenesis or dysplasia leading to oligohydramnios and subsequent pulmonary hypoplasia.
  • Clinical features include flattened nose, low-set ears, limb deformities, and widely spaced eyes. It can be lethal in the neonatal period.

Other options:

 

Option A. Trisomy 21. The clinical features mentioned in this case is not consistent with Down Syndrome. In case of it there will be clinical features of intellectual disability, Mongoloid slant of yes, large tongue and single simian crease will be mentioned.

 

Option C. Patau syndrome. Trisomy 13 it also shows features of cleft lip and palate and VSD whereas the other symptoms are only characteristic of Potters syndrome.

 

Option D. Turner syndrome. The clinical features mentioned in this case is not consistent with Turner Syndrome. In case of it there will be clinical features of short stature, widely placed nipples, shield type chest will be seen.

 

 

Ref: Nelson, 20th Edition, Page No. 2554

choices.text: Amniotic fluid index
Deepest vertical pocket of liquor
BPD and HC

questions.text: The image below shows measurement of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amniotic fluid index

 

AMNIOTIC FLUID INDEX (AFI)

  • The ultrasound transducer is held perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the long axis of the woman.
  • The uterus is divided into 4 equal quadrants – right and left upper and lower quadrants.
  • The AFI is the sum of the single deepest pocket from each quadrant.
  • So the unit of measurement is mm/cm.
  • Normal value: 5-25 (ACOG)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Deepest vertical pocket. This is another method to determine the amniotic fluid volume. In this only the largest vertical pocket of liquor is measured.

 

Option C. BPD and HC. These are fetal measurements (Biparietal diameter and Head circumference).

 

Option D. Cervical length. This is measured at 11-14 weeks. A measurement of < 2,5 cm before 24 weeks is a risk factor for preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Amniotic fluid volume can be measured by:
    • Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) wherein the amniotic fluid is measured vertically in 4 quadrants and then added up. Normal values are within 5-25.
    • Deepest vertical pocket: This is preferred before 28 weeks and in twin pregnancy. Normal values re between 2 to 8.

 

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no. 227

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with a history of bipolar disorder has been taking lithium throughout her pregnancy. Her neonate should be screened for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cardiac anomalies

  • Lithium is a mood stabilizer commonly used in the treatment of bipolar disorder.
  • However, it is associated with an increased risk of Ebstein’s anomaly characterized by congenital heart defects, especially when taken during the first trimester of pregnancy.
  • Therefore, neonates born to mothers who took lithium during pregnancy should be screened for cardiac anomalies.
  • It can also result in neonatal goitre.

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Circumvallate

  • The given histological image is a section of the tongue displaying circumvallate papillae, which are the largest papillae present on the tongue.
  • They are cylindrical in shape, and usually around 8-12 in no.
  • They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and are arranged in a V-shaped row immediately in front of the sulcus terminalis on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
  • They are narrower at their base than their apex and contain numerous taste buds (around 250 for each papilla) within their walls.
  • These taste buds contain chemosensory cells that synapse with the gustatory nerves, enabling the sense of taste.
  • In addition, the serous glands of von Ebner empty via ducts into the base of the sulcus, which helps to flush out food particles from the area surrounding the papillae.

 

Let’s delve into other options:

 

Option A. Fungiform.

  • Fungiform papillae are protrusions on the tongue that are relatively large, round, and reddish in color.
  • They can be found on both the dorsal surface and the lingual margins of the tongue, and are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

Option C. Filiform.

  • Filiform papillae are small, conical or cylindrical projections located mainly on the dorsal surface of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • They lack taste buds and are covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.
  • All other papillae, except filiform, contain taste buds.

Option D. Foliate.  

  • Foliate papillae are red, leaf-like mucosal ridges located bilaterally in two zones at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis.
  • They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

questions.text: A baby was recently delivered in the labor room. The mother was found to have diabetes. After the delivery of the infant of diabetic mother, blood glucose of the infant was measured to be 60 mg/dl. What other investigation does the sister expect that the physician would ask her to do next?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Serum calcium

  • Infants of a diabetic mother are at a higher risk of metabolic complications as complications to normal infants.
  • These complications include:
    • Hypoglycemia
    • Hypocalcemia
    • Hypomagnesemia
       
  • Hence, the infant needs to be checked for these as soon as possible.
  • Therefore, the correct options will be Serum Calcium levels.

Other options:

 

Option A. Serum potassium. In the case of Infant of a diabetic mother, serum calcium is measured whereas Serum potassium has less or no significance.

 

Option B. CBC. Polycythemia is also an associated feature in infant of diabetic mother, so CBC can be done but Serum Calcium is prioritized.

 

Option C. Serum calcium. In the case of Infant of a diabetic mother, serum calcium is measured whereas Serum chloride has less or no significance.

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai, 9th Edition

choices.text: Basal cell carcinoma
Transitional cell carcinoma
Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: Dr. Roy, a senior urologist at a renowned medical college in India, is giving a lecture to MBBS students about occupational health hazards and their presentations. He shares a case of a 55-year-old male patient who comes to the OPD complaining of bladder issues. Dr. Roy mentions that the patient has a long history of working in the dye industry where aniline is a primary component. Based on the patient's occupational exposure and his symptoms, which of the following conditions is most likely to be diagnosed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Transitional cell carcinoma

  • Aniline exposure is carcinogenic to bladder and most common cancer it can cause is Transitional cell carcinoma. 
  • Carcinoma Bladder in Occupational Exposures:
    • Cancer bladder was first noted in man in Aniline industry in 1895.
    • Now, following has been mentioned as possible bladder carcinogens:
      • Beta-napthylamines
      • Benzidine
      • Paraamino-diphenyl
      • Auramine
      • Magenta
      • Certain drugs: Cyclophosphamide, Phenacetin
         
    • Industries associated with cancer bladder:
      • Dye-stuffs and dyeing industry
      • Rubber, gas and electric cable industry
         
  • Most common symptom: Blood in the urine (haematuria)
  • Most common type: Transitional Cell (urothelial cell) carcinoma (TCC) [90%]
  • Immunotherapy in the form of ‘Intravesical (pharmacotherapeutic) BCG instillation’ is also used to treat and prevent the recurrence of superficial tumors.

questions.text: A 25-year-old type 1 diabetic with ESRD underwent simultaneous pancreatic-kidney transplant (SPK). Which of these is not a complication of bladder drainage of transplanted pancreas?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Metabolic alkalosis

 

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery, 28th edition, page no. 1627

questions.text: Free radial artery forearm flap (FRAFF) is a type of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fasciocutaenous flap

 

 

  • The radial forearm flap is a fascio-cutaneous flap based on the “fascio-cutaneous perforators” from the radial artery.
  • The number of perforators is greatest between 12 and 20 cm from the takeoff of the radial artery, and these are the vessels captured in the distally located skin paddle.
  • It is commonly used in reconstruction of oral cancer resections like tongue.

Other options:

 

Option A. Myocutaneous flap. This type of flap includes both muscle and skin tissue. E.g., Pectoralis major myocutaneous flap.

 

Option B. Osseomyocutaneous flap. This flap contains bone, muscle, and skin tissue. E.g., Free fibular flap.

 

Option C. Subcutaneous flap. This flap comprises the subcutaneous layer of fat along with the skin but does not include deeper structures like muscle or fascia. E.g., Deltopectoral flap.

 

Option D. Fasciocutaneous flap. This flap includes skin and fascia, and sometimes a small amount of muscle may be included to support the blood vessels. It is based on the fasciocutaneous perforators, such as those from the radial artery in the case of the FRAFF.

 

Educational objective:

 

Common tissue transfer donor sites:

  1. Muscle only: Latissimus dorsi, Rectus abdominis, Gracilis
  2. Myocutaneous: Latissimus dorsi, Transverse rectus abdominis
  3. Fasciocutaneous: Radial forearm flap, Scapular, Lateral arm, Anterolateral thigh, Groin
  4. Osseous: Fibula (may be cutaneous as well), Forearm (taking sliver of radius bone), Iliac crest
  5. Fascial: Temporoparietal

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery, 28th edition, page no. 823-824; Bailey, 27th Edition. Table 42.2

choices.text: This disease begins at the rectum and moves proximally.
Smoking is a risk factor.
The fulminant disease is characterized by more than 10 bowel movements in a day.
The disease is limited to mucosa and submucosa only.

questions.text: A 30 years old patient presented with tenesmus and rectal bleeding. On endoscopy, the following picture was obtained. Mark the FALSE statement with respect to the above condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Smoking is a risk factor

  • Given colonoscopy is of ulcerative colitis (UC), showing continuous ulcers (no skip areas).
  • Smoking is protective for UC.
  • UC is characterised by mucosal inflammation of the large bowel, always involving the rectum (proctitis) and extending to involve varying degrees of more proximal colon (colitis).
  • When the entire colon and rectum are involved (pancolitis), some patients may also have a degree of ‘backwash ileitis’, in which there is secondary inflammation in the terminal ileum.
  • Truelove and Witt severity of UC:
  1. Mild: <4 stools/day, Moderate 4 to 6/day, no systemic illness
  2. Severe: > 6 stools/day, hypoalbuminemia, systemic illness
  3. Fulminant: >10/day, toxic megacolon

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Edition, Page no. 1319

choices.text: Annual Parasite incidence
Infant Parasite rate
Spleen rate
Slide positivity rate

questions.text: Dr. Anjali, an epidemiologist in a small district of Jharkhand, is concerned about a sudden surge in the number of malaria cases, especially in children. To establish if there's a recent increase in the transmission of the malarial parasite in the community, she intends to use a specific metric. Which of the following indices would Dr. Anjali most likely employ to determine the recent transmission of malaria in her community?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Infant parasite rate

 

INFANT PARASITE RATE (IPR)

 

 

  • Most sensitive index for recent transmission of malaria.
  • If IFR is zero for 3 consecutive years, it is regarded as absence of malaria transmission (even though anopheline may remain).
  • Parasite rate: Percentage children of 2-10 years age showing parasites in blood films.

questions.text: A patient with a ruptured spleen is taken for a laparotomy. His blood pressure is 80/50 and heart rate is 125/min. Induction agent of choice for this patient is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ketamine

  • Ketamine is a dissociative anaesthetic that increases blood pressure and maintains cardiac output, making it a suitable induction agent for patients with hypotension.
  • Ketamine acts by blocking NMDA receptors, which leads to dissociative anaesthesia, analgesia, and amnesia.
  • In addition to its hemodynamic stability, ketamine has a rapid onset of action and produces minimal respiratory depression.
  • Other options like Sodium thiopentone (Option A), Fentanyl (Option B) and, Halothane (Option D) can cause hypotension making them unsuitable for a patient with hypotension.

questions.text: Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. ABCC2

  • Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is ABCC2 (codes for canalicular protein with ATP-binding cassette), it leads to the mutation of multiple drug-resistant protein 2 (MRP2) receptor.
  • Hence, there is a defect in the transfer of conjugated bilirubin from the liver to bile in Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

Other options:

 

Option A. ATP7A – Menke’s disease

 

Option B. ATP7B – Wilson’s disease

 

Option D. SERPINA1 – Alpha 1 Antitrypsin deficiency

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination, there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which nerve is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Musculocutaneous nerve

 

  • The clinical vignette presented in a patient with difficulty flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, as well as loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm, is suggestive of musculocutaneous nerve injury.
  • One of the most common causes of humerus fractures is a fall from a great height on an outstretched hand.

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab was cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe and the test that is shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of infection in the case of a burn.
  • The given image shows a positive oxidase test.
  • Psuedomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe and shows a positive oxidase reaction.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility.
  • They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin.
  • Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown).
  • Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include:
    • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
    • Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
    • Wound infection and sepsis in burns
    • Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure.
    • Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
    • Ecthyma gangrenosum
       
  • Pathogenesis: It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green coloured colonies are shown in the image below.

 

  • Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase.
  • Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen.
  • Enterobacteriacee (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.
  • Oxidase positive organisms:
    • Pseudomonas
    • Vibrio
    • Helicobacter
    • Campylobacter
    • Pasteurella
    • Legionella
    • Neisseria
    • Brucella
    • Moraxella
    • Burkholderia

choices.text: Posterior interosseus nerve

questions.text: Identify the Sensory nerve supply for the given area of hand.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Radial nerve 

  • The area marked in the image is supplied by radial nerve.

 

The sensory function of the radial nerve is provided by its four main sensory branches:

  • Lower lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm: Supplies the lateral aspect of the anterior upper arm between the deltoid and the elbow.
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm: Supplies part of the posterior aspect of the upper arm.
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the forearm: Supplies a tapered strip of the middle portion of the posterior forearm.
  • Superficial branch of the radial nerve: Supplies the posterior surface of the lateral 3 ½ digits and the associated areas of the palm.

Let’s consider the other options:

 

Option A. Radial Nerve.

  • Origin: Arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Primarily a motor nerve for the extensor muscles of the arm and forearm. It also has sensory branches for the skin on the back of the hand and the posterior arm and forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: Triceps brachii, anconeus, brachioradialis, and all the extensor muscles in the forearm.
  • Sensory Innervation: Supplies the posterior surface of the arm and forearm, and the radial aspect of the dorsum of the hand.

Option B. Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN).

  • Origin: It's a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve.
  • Main Functions: Purely motor nerve that supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: All the deep extensors of the forearm, including extensor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, extensor indicis, and others.
  • Sensory Innervation: The PIN does not have a sensory function.

Option C. Median Nerve.

  • Origin: Formed by the union of the medial and lateral roots from the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Supplies most of the flexor muscles in the forearm and some muscles in the hand.
  • Motor Innervation: Flexor muscles in the anterior forearm (except flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus) and thenar muscles and first two lumbricals in the hand.
  • Sensory Innervation: Palmar aspect of the lateral three and a half fingers and the associated palm area.

Option D. Ulnar Nerve.

  • Origin: Arises from the medial cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Supplies muscles in the hand and a few in the forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: Flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus in the forearm. In the hand, it supplies most intrinsic muscles, including the hypothenar muscles, the palmar and dorsal interossei, and the third and fourth lumbricals.
  • Sensory Innervation: Provides sensation to the palmar and dorsal aspects of the medial one and a half fingers and the associated hand region.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female with rheumatoid arthritis is planned for immunosuppressive therapy. She has been advised to do a Mantoux test to screen for TB exposure in the past. What is the immune mechanism behind this?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. T cells

  • The given example is a feature of Type 4 hypersensitivity mediated by cellular immunity.

 

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No. 184

questions.text: The nigrostriatal projections to the striatum within the basal ganglia is associated with which neurotransmitter?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Dopamine

  • There will be two major outputs to the thalamus from the basal ganglia from the globus pallidus internus and from the substantia nigra pars reticulata.
  • There will be connections within the basal ganglia also, from the substantia nigra to the striatum.
  • The nigrostriatal projection will be from the substantia nigra (pars compacta) to the striatum, which is dopaminergic in nature (dopamine will be the neurotransmitter).

 

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, page no. 244

choices.text: Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis
Inhibition of ergosterol synthesis
Forms pores in fungal membranes
Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi

questions.text: What is the mechanism of triazoles?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inhibition of ergosterol synthesis

  • Triazoles include drugs like Itraconazole, Voriconazole, Fluconazole and Posaconazole.
  • They are antifungal drugs that act by inhibiting 14-α demethylase, which prevents the conversion of Lanosterol to Ergosterol, thereby inhibiting the fungal cell wall synthesis.

choices.text: Cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to acute heart failure.
Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

questions.text: A 42-year-old female with no significant past medical history is admitted to the intensive care unit following a severe bacterial pneumonia. She initially presented with a high fever, productive cough, and was found to have a right lower lobe consolidation on chest X-ray. Despite appropriate antibiotic therapy, her condition worsens over the next 48 hours. She develops increasing shortness of breath, hypoxemia, and requires supplemental oxygen. A repeat chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Her blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg, heart rate is 95 bpm, and there is no evidence of left heart failure on echocardiogram. Considering the patient’s recent medical history and current clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

  • This patient's clinical progression, characterized by worsening respiratory distress and hypoxemia with new bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, is indicative of ARDS, which often develops in the setting of severe infections like pneumonia.
  • ARDS is characterized by non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema resulting from increased permeability of the pulmonary capillary endothelium, leading to fluid accumulation in the alveolar spaces.
  • The absence of evidence of left heart failure on echocardiogram and the normal blood pressure readings make cardiogenic pulmonary edema unlikely.
  • While pulmonary embolism and an exacerbation of bacterial pneumonia are plausible considerations, the rapid onset of bilateral infiltrates and severe hypoxemia without obvious signs of heart failure or thromboembolic disease point more towards ARDS.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male, a long-time smoker, presents with a year-long history of progressive breathlessness and a dry cough. He has no history of environmental exposures or connective tissue diseases. Physical examination reveals fine bibasal crackles on lung auscultation. High-resolution CT (HRCT) of the chest shown below. Pulmonary function tests indicate a restrictive pattern with reduced diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP)

  • The patient's history of progressive breathlessness, dry cough, smoking history, HRCT findings of subpleural, basal-predominant reticular abnormalities with honeycombing, and a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests are classic for Usual Interstitial Pneumonia, a form of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF).
  • UIP is typically seen in older adults and is associated with a worse prognosis than other forms of interstitial lung disease.

Other options:

 

Option A. Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). COPD, often related to smoking, typically presents with a history of productive cough and shows an obstructive pattern on pulmonary function tests, which is not consistent with this patient's presentation and imaging findings.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a multi-system granulomatous disorder that often presents with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, lung infiltrates, and can affect multiple organs. The specific HRCT findings of UIP are not typical for sarcoidosis.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis. This rare smoking-related lung disease is characterized by nodular and cystic changes predominantly in the upper and mid lung zones, which is different from the HRCT findings in this case.

choices.text: Both clomiphene citrate and letrozole

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with infertility and is diagnosed with anovulatory cycles. Which of the following medications can be used for ovulation induction in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both clomiphene citrate and letrozole

 

Explanation of all options:

 

Option A. Clomiphene citrate is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that blocks the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, leading to increased production and release of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). This promotes follicular growth and ovulation.

 

Option B. Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor that reduces the conversion of androgens to estrogen, leading to decreased estrogen levels and increased FSH production. It has been found to be equally effective or even superior to clomiphene citrate in some cases, particularly in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

 

Option D. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are not typically used for primary ovulation induction. They are more commonly used to suppress ovulation temporarily in certain fertility treatment protocols or for medical management of specific conditions, such as endometriosis.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Drug of choice in infertility in a woman with anovulation: Letrozole (PCOS) and Clomiphene citrate)
  • Gonadotropins are the 2nd line management in anovulation in infertility.

questions.text: All are regimes of MgSO4 for treatment of eclampsia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Magpie regime

 

Various regimes of MgSO4 for eclampsia:

  1. Pritchard Regime (most commonly used in India):
    • Initial dose: 20% MgSo4 – 4g IV slowly over 4 mins (1g/min) as 20 ml followed by 5g in each buttock as 10ml of 50% MgSO4
    • Maintenance dose: 5g of 50% MgSO4 IM in alternate buttocks 4 hourly till 24 h or till delivery, whichever is later.
  2. Sibai regime:
    • Loading dose: 6g MgSO4 IV over 15-20 mins f/b IV infusion 2g/h as maintenance dose
    • Recommended by ACOG
  3. Zuspan Regime:
    • Loading dose: 4g IV MgSO4 f/b IV infusion of 1g/h until 24 h after delivery
  4. Dhaka regime:
    • Lower dose of MgSO4 (Half of Pritchard’s)
    • Loading dose is 4g IV over 15 mins
    • Following this, 3 g MgSO4 IM in each buttock 4 hourly for 24 h after administration of 1st dose.
    • This regime was developed with South-East Asian women’s smaller body habitus in mind to reduce the risk of Mg toxicity as compared to Pritchard regime.

 

Magpie is not a regime. It was a large multicentric study to determine the usefulness of MgSO4 for prophylaxis for eclampsia in women with severe preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Different regimes are there for MgSO4 for treatment of eclampsia.
  • The most common is Pritchard regime.
  • Other regimes that have been described are:
    • Sibai regime
    • Dhaka regime
    • Zuspan regime

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr. JB Sharma, 1st edition, Page no. 439

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss in the same side
Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

questions.text: Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

  • Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side.
  • The first order neurons carry sensory information regarding touch, proprioception or vibration from the peripheral nerves to the medulla oblongata by two different pathways -
  • Signals from the upper limb (T6 and above) travel in the fasciculus cuneatus (the lateral part of the dorsal column). They then, synapse in the nucleus cuneatus of the medulla oblongata.
  • Signals from the lower limb (below T6) travel in the fasciculus gracilis (the medial part of the dorsal column). They then, synapse in the nucleus gracilis of the medulla oblongata.
  • The second order neuron begin in the cuneate nucleus or gracilis. The fibers receive the information from the preceding neuron, and delivers it to the third order neuron in the thalamus. Within the medulla oblongata, these fibers decussate (cross to the other side of the CNS). They then travel in the contralateral medial lemniscus to reach the thalamus.
  • Lastly, the third order neuron transmit the sensory signals from the thalamus to the ipsilateral primary sensory cortex of the brain. They ascend from the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus, travel through the internal capsule and terminate at the sensory cortex.

choices.text: Caudal regression syndrome is a commonly associated anomaly seen in diabetes.
The risk of anomalies in the fetus is inversely proportional to the level of HBA1c.
Folic acid in a dose of 5 mg/day started in the preconception period will not reduce the risk of neural tube defects.
Metformin and Glyburide can be safely continued in pregnancy even though they cross the placenta.

questions.text: A 36-year-old diabetic woman on insulin is planning conception. She is worried about the risk of fetal congenital anomalies and visits for preconception counseling. Which of the following is the correct statement?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Metformin and Glyburide can be safely continued in pregnancy even though they cross the placenta.

  • Both metformin and glyburide cross the placenta, but evidence has shown they are safe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The most common anomaly in diabetic mothers is congenital heart disease and the most specific (albeit rare) anomaly in diabetic mothers is caudal regression syndrome (mermaid syndrome).

 

Option B. The higher the HBA1C level preconceptionally; the higher the risk of fetal anomalies.

 

Option C. Folic acid in a dose of 5 mg/day started in the preconception period will reduce the risk of neural tube defects.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Metformin and Glyburide are safe in pregnancy.

 

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no. 1110

questions.text: A woman presents with a breast tumor of size 6 x 3cm, with adherence to the pectoralis major muscle. Overlying skin shows dimpling. As her surgeon, what will you designate her T staging as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. T3

  • The tumor is of size 6cm. Hence it is stage T3 (>5cm).
  • Fixity to pectoralis major doesn’t affect staging. Skin dimpling is not classified as T4b.

Educational Objective:

  • Irrelevant to the size of the tumor, if the tumor shows extension to the chest wall or skin, it is classified as T4. However, there are two exceptions.
  • Invasion or adherence to pectoralis muscle in the absence of chest wall involvement does not qualify as T4.
  • Similarly, involvement of the dermis in the form of dimpling/puckering/retraction of nipple does not qualify as T4.

Points to Remember:

  • In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6 X 3 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3 (>5 cm).
  • Skin involvement does not include nipple retraction and skin dimpling.
  • Supraclavicular lymph node involvement indicates N3c.
  • Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.
  • If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump.
  • If lumps are present in both breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-year-old boy to the clinic with a history of hearing loss, cataracts, and heart defects since birth. On examination, he has a low-grade fever, rash, and lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features given?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Rubella

  • The clinical features mentioned in the case, including hearing loss, cataracts, and heart defects, are classic findings in Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS).
  • The clinical features of hearing loss, cataracts, heart defects, fever, rash, and lymphadenopathy are highly suggestive of Congenital Rubella Syndrome.
  • CRS is a condition that results from a mother's infection with the rubella virus during pregnancy, which can cause a range of birth defects in the developing foetus.
  • Additionally, the presence of a low-grade fever, rash, and lymphadenopathy further supports the diagnosis of rubella.

Other options:

 

Option A. Mumps typically presents with swelling of the salivary glands while measles (Option C) presents with a rash, high fever, and cough

.

Option D. Chickenpox presents with a characteristic pruritic vesicular rash that typically starts on the trunk and spreads to the limbs.

 

 

Ref: Nelson, 20th Edition, Page No. 1579-1585

choices.text: Electrocution
Lightening
Thermal burn
Chemical burn

questions.text: Litchenberg flower is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lightening

  • Lichtenberg’s flower, also called as Filigree or Arbore scent burns, are Pathognomonic of lightening injury.
  • These are Superficial, thin, irregular and tortuous marking over skin mainly over shoulders and flanks.
  • They are caused by slight staining of tissue by hemoglobin from lysed RBCs along path of current.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrocution. Electrocution refers to injury or death caused by electric shock. While high-voltage electrical injuries can sometimes create patterns on the skin due to the path of the electrical current, the unique, fern-like fractal patterns known as Lichtenberg figures are not typically used to describe injuries from man-made electrical sources.

 

Option C. Thermal burn. Thermal burns are caused by an external heat source, such as fire, hot metals, scalding liquids, or steam, and can damage the skin and tissues. They do not create the fern-like fractal pattern of Lichtenberg figures. The damage from thermal burns usually appears as reddened, blistered, or charred skin depending on the severity of the burn.

 

Option D.  Chemical burn. Chemical burns occur when skin or tissues are exposed to corrosive substances such as acids or alkalis. The resulting injuries can vary widely in appearance depending on the chemical involved but typically do not exhibit the fractal pattern seen with Lichtenberg figures. Instead, chemical burns might result in necrosis or ulceration of the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LICHTENBERG’S FLOWER

  • Also called as Filigree or Arbore scent burns.
  • Pathognomonic of lightening injury.
  • Superficial, thin, irregular and tortuous marking over skin mainly over shoulders and flanks.
  • Resembles branches of a tree (Fern-like pattern) of erythema.
  • Not associated with burning.
  • May be caused by slight staining of tissue by hemoglobin from lysed RBCs along path of current.
  • Indicates the path taken by current but does not correspond to vascular channels.
  • Disappears in 1 or 2 days if survives.

questions.text: A young child complained to his parents that he was touched inappropriately by a neighbor.  On examination by a doctor in the OPD, he complained of pain when touched in the perianal area. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine pirate. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Barberio test

  • As the crystals are seen under the microscope, this indicates that it is a microchemical test.
  • Difficultly in walking and pain in perianal region may indicate towards sexual abuse of the child.
  • Microchemical tests for Semen are Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests).
  • Yellow needle shaped crystals are composed of spermine picrate and is seen in Barberio test.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Florence test. This test is also for semen, but it is incorrect as the crystals of choline iodide are dark brown rhombic shaped.

 

Option D. Takayama test. This option is incorrect as the crystal seen are pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen and is used to detect blood.

 

Option D. Teichmann test. This option is incorrect as the crystal seen are brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride and is used to detect blood.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)
  • Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

MICROCHEMICAL TESTS FOR SEMEN

1. Florence test:

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

 

2. Barberio’s test:

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

 

MICROCHEMICAL TESTS FOR BLOOD STAINS

1. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

    • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
    • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
    • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

2. Hemochromogen (Takayama) test:

    • Reagent: NaOH + pyridine + glucose
    • Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

questions.text: The most common aneuploidy causing non-immune hydrops is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Turner syndrome

 

Etiology of non-immune hydrops:

    • Aneuploidy (20%): MC – 45 XO (Turner Syndrome)
    • Cardiovascular (15%)
    • Infections (15%): Most common – Parvovirus B19

 

Educational Objective:

  • Aneuploidy is the most common aneuploidy causing non-immune hydrops, out of which Turner syndrome is the most common.

 

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no. 309

choices.text: USG of swelling
MRI of swelling
FNAC of swelling
Core biopsy of swelling

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented in OPD with a swelling that has been slowly growing in the past 2 years. On examination, it was variable in consistency and mobile. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. USG of swelling

  • The given clinical scenario and image points to a diagnosis of parotid tumor.
  • First investigation in all head and neck swellings is USG, which is also a “work horse imaging” for neck swellings.
  • MC benign parotid tumor is Pleomorphic Adenoma.
  • MC site: superficial lobe of parotid

choices.text: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of recurrent headaches and pulsatile tinnitus in her left ear. She has also noticed a throbbing sensation in her neck, especially on the left side. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg in the right arm and 160/100 mm Hg in the left arm. There is a prominent bruit heard on auscultation over the left carotid artery. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD)

 

FIBROMUSCULAR DYSPLASIA (FMD)

  • FMD is a nonatherosclerotic, noninflammatory vascular disease that most commonly affects medium-sized arteries, particularly the renal and carotid arteries.
  • In this case, the patient's symptoms, including pulsatile tinnitus, throbbing sensation in the neck, and the presence of a bruit over the left carotid artery, are consistent with carotid artery involvement, which is a characteristic feature of FMD.
  • Additionally, the difference in blood pressure between the two arms, with higher pressure on the left side, is a classic finding in patients with carotid artery FMD.
  • The DSA appearance reveals the typical “string of pearls” or “beaded” appearance in the renal artery.

Other options:

 

Option A. PAN (Polyarteritis nodosa). PAN is an autoimmune vasculitis that typically affects small and medium-sized arteries. The DSA appearance of PAN will reveal small microaneurysms in the renal artery branches.

 

 

Option B. Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension (IIH). IIH is characterized by increased intracranial pressure, leading to symptoms like headaches and pulsatile tinnitus. However, it is not associated with carotid artery involvement or differences in blood pressure between arms.

 

Option D. Takayasu's Arteritis. Takayasu's arteritis is another vasculitis that predominantly affects large arteries, including the aorta and its branches. It can lead to symptoms related to arterial stenosis but the DSA will not show the typical “string of pearls” or “beaded” appearance in the renal artery and will show asymmetrical narrowing related to inflammation.

choices.text: Leucine catabolism defect
Tyrosinemia type 1
Maple syrup urine disease

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby presented by its mother with a complaint of cabbage odor urine. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tyrosinemia type 1        

  • Hepatorenal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type I) is an autosomal recessive condition due to a deficiency of enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase.
  • Symptoms usually appear within the first 6 months of life which includes mild mental retardation, cabbage-like odor in urine, hypoglycemia, liver failure and finally death occurs.

 

 

Incorrect answers:

 

Option A. Leucine catabolism defect. Isovaleric Acidemia – Sweaty feet odor

 

Option B. Hawkinsinuria. Swimming pool odor

 

Option D. Maple syrup urine disease. Maple syrup odor in urine

questions.text: A 70-year-old hypertensive patient with stage 5 chronic kidney disease was diagnosed recently with Type 2 diabetes mellitus. He does not want to take injectable drugs. Which of the following oral hypoglycemic agents will be preferred in this patient that does not require any dose modification in renal failure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Linagliptin

 

Linagliptin:

  • It is an incretin-mimetic drug that act by increasing the level of endogenous GLP-1.
  • It inhibits the metabolism of GLP-1 by inhibiting DPP-4 enzyme.
  • Gliptins are given orally.
  • Linagliptin is predominantly excreted via enterohepatic system and is therefore safe in patients with renal failure (only gliptin).
  • It is approved for use as monotherapy and in combination with metformin, glimepiride, and pioglitazone.

Vildagliptin:

  • It acts via a mechanism like linagliptin.
  • It is also incretin-mimetic drug that act by increasing the level of endogenous GLP-1.
  • It inhibits the metabolism of GLP-1 by inhibiting DPP-4 enzyme.
  • Gliptins are given orally.
  • It requires dose modification in renal like all the gliptins (except linagliptin).

Exenatide:

  • It is a long-acting analogue of GLP-1.
  • It needs to be given by injectable route because it not effective orally due to its peptide structure.

Metformin:

  • Normally, metformin is DOC for type 2 diabetes mellitus.
  • However, it is contra-indicated in renal disease due to risk of development of lactic acidosis.

Risk factors for metformin induced lactic acidosis:

  • Hypotensive states
  • Cardiovascular disease
  • Respiratory disease
  • Hepatic failure
  • Renal failure
  • Alcoholics

choices.text: Pneumatised superior turbinate

questions.text: Identify the following structure marked:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Concha bullosa

  • Concha bullosa refers to the pneumatization of the middle turbinate. It is one of the most common variations of PNS anatomy.

Other options:

 

Option C. Bulla ethmoidalis. Onodi air cell is the posteriormost ethmoidal air cell, important due to its proximity to the optic nerve and internal carotid artery.

 

Option B. Haller cells are infraorbital ethmoidal air cells, along the inferomedial orbital floor.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman undergoes a diagnostic laparoscopy for infertility. On putting the secondary trocar, she starts bleeding profusely from the port site. Which vessel is injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inferior epigastric

  • The vessels most commonly injured during accessory (or ancillary) trocar placement are the superficial inferior epigastric vessels as they branch from the femoral artery and vein and course cephalad in each lower quadrant.
  • The deep inferior epigastric vessels can also be injured. These are branches of the external iliac artery and course cephalad. They are deep to the rectus sheath and muscle.
  • Great vessel injury (abdominal aorta and vena cava, common iliac and their branches) commonly occur following insertion of an insufflation needle or the tip of the primary trocar.

 

Educational Objective:

  • The vessels most commonly injured during accessory (or ancillary) trocar placement are the superficial inferior epigastric vessels as they branch from the femoral artery and vein and course cephalad in each lower quadrant.

 

 

Ref: Novak’s Gynecology, 15th edition, Page no. 780

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of sporadic shortness of breath and recurrent pneumothorax presents to the clinic. She mentions having irregular menses but no significant family history of lung disease. A high-resolution CT scan of the chest reveals multiple thin-walled cysts scattered throughout both lung fields. Her pulmonary function tests show a moderate reduction in diffusing capacity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pulmonary Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)

  • A rare lung disease more common in women, often characterized by thin-walled cysts throughout the lungs.
  • Symptoms include shortness of breath and recurrent pneumothorax, which aligns well with this patient's presentation.

Other options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary Tuberculosis. Typically presents with symptoms like cough, weight loss, and fever. CT scans may show nodules, consolidations, or cavitations, but thin-walled cysts are not characteristic of tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Cystic Fibrosis. A genetic disorder that typically presents in childhood, primarily affecting the lungs and digestive system. It can lead to chronic lung infections and bronchiectasis, but the presence of multiple thin-walled cysts in an adult patient without a prior diagnosis is less typical for cystic fibrosis.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis. A multi-system inflammatory disease often involving the lungs, characterized by the formation of granulomas. It can cause lung fibrosis, but the pattern of multiple thin-walled cysts seen in this patient's CT scan is not typical for sarcoidosis.

questions.text: Which of these is the most common functional neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Insulinoma

  • The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is C. Insulinoma.
  • These tumors are derived from the beta cells of the pancreas and are often associated with excessive insulin production, leading to hypoglycemia.

Other options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma.

  • Gastrinoma is a type of neuroendocrine tumor that primarily arises in the pancreas or duodenum.
  • This condition can result in peptic ulcers, acid reflux, and gastrin-related symptoms (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome).
  • Gastrinomas are often associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1).

Option B. Somatostatinoma.

  • Somatostatinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that can occur in various parts of the gastrointestinal tract, including the pancreas.
  • These tumors produce excessive amounts of somatostatin, a hormone that inhibits the release of other hormones.
  • Symptoms may include diabetes mellitus, diarrhea, and gallstones.
  • Diagnosis and management often involve surgical removal and somatostatin analog medications.

Option D. VIPoma.

  • VIPoma, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is a rare neuroendocrine tumor typically found in the pancreas.
  • It produces excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), leading to severe diarrhea and electrolyte imbalances.
  • Patients with VIPoma often experience "WDHA syndrome" (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, Achlorhydria).
  • Treatment involves addressing fluid and electrolyte imbalances and managing the tumor.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with acute onset watery diarrhea. The mother reports that the child had 6 episodes of diarrhea in the last 24 hours. The child has no fever, abdominal pain, or vomiting. The child is alert and well hydrated. On examination, the abdomen is soft and non-tender. What is the most common infectious cause of diarrhea in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Rota virus

  • The most common viral infectious cause of diarrhoea is Rota virus.

Other options:

 

Option A. Rhino virus is the most common cause of upper respiratory tract infection in children

 

Option C. Noro virus is the most common cause of diarrhoea in adults

 

Option D. Zika virus will results in microcephaly.

 

 

Ref: Nelson, 21st Edition, Chapter 292, Page No. 7022

choices.text: Transmitted by Culex vishnui.
Pig is the amplifier host.
Man acts as the reservoir.
Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Man acts as the reservoir.

  • Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus.
  • Japanese encephalitis is a viral infection caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which belongs to the Flavivirus family.
  • Symptoms of Japanese encephalitis can range from mild, flu-like illness to severe neurological complications, such as high fever, headache, neck stiffness, disorientation, seizures, paralysis, and even coma.

Other options:

 

Option A. The disease is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

 

Option B. Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts.

 

Option D. The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings and vaccinating pigs.

choices.text: Loeffler’s serum slope
Lowenstein Jensen media
Potassium tellurite media
Thayer martin medium

questions.text: A patient with a history of cough for more than 15 days, fever and loss of weight presented to OPD. Sputum culture was advised and the following media was used for inoculation. Identify the culture media:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lowenstein Jensen media

  • The clinical picture here shows an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • LJ medium: Lowenstein Jensen medium is used for primary isolation of Mycobacterium species.
  • It also promotes the growth of Nocardia sp.
  • The ingredients are Mineral salts, asparagine, glycerol, malachite green and egg.

Other options:

 

Option A. Loeffler’s serum slope and Option C. Potassium tellurite blood agar is used for C. diphtheriae

 

Option D. Thayer martin medium is used for the isolation of N. gonorrhea.

 

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Chapter 2, Page No. 29

questions.text: A mother brings her child with features of fever, swelling and pain during movement of leg. On physical examination, signs of inflammation were present. CBC examination reveals the increased levels of neutrophils along with a microcytic anaemia. A case of osteomyelitis is suspected. On taking history, the child is found to have sickle cell disease. Which of the following organisms is responsible for osteomyelitis in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Salmonella enteritidis

  • Organisms responsible for osteomyelitis are:
    • In normal population – Staphylococcus aureus
    • In sickle cell patients, Salmonella enteritidis is the M/C cause.

Other options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pyogenes is not responsible for the osteomyelitis in this case

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of osteomyelitis but not in sickle cell anaemia.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in IV drug abusers.

 

 

Ref: Nelson, 21st Edition

questions.text: Which one of the enzyme deficiencies are correctly matched?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fabry alpha galactosidase                      

 

 

Incorrect answers:

 

Option B. Gauchers disease. Due to deficiency of Glucocerebrosidase (Beta glucosidase).

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis. A point mutation in CFTR gene results in defective chloride transport.

 

Option D. Chronic bronchitis might result from exposure to acid fumes, Nitrogen dioxide, Sulphur dioxide etc.

choices.text: Total/Near total thyroidectomy
Continue antithyroid medication

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady with painless neck swelling presented with palpitations and weight loss. Her thyroid function tests were done which revealed elevated T3, T4, low TSH and negative TSH-RAb. Iodine scan showed multiple thyroid nodules with increased iodine uptake. She was started on initial anti-thyroid treatment. What will be your next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Total/Near total thyroidectomy

  • The given scenario is suggestive of toxic multinodular goitre. The next step of management once a euthyroid state is achieved is a near total thyroidectomy. Toxic nodular goitres are often large, uncomfortable, and are prone to recurrence.
  • In a developing country like India, a near total thyroidectomy eliminates the risk of recurrence and simplifies follow-up. However, it causes immediate thyroid failure and necessitates lifelong thyroxine replacement.

Other options:

 

Option B. Continue antithyroid medication. Toxic multi nodular goiters show decreased response to anti thyroid drugs or may even enlarge further. Hence, surgery is recommended.

 

Option C. Sub-total thyroidectomies have high recurrence.

 

Option D. Radioactive iodine. Large goiters show decreased response to radioactive iodine, and also have an increased chance of recurrence.

questions.text: The scope of Project MONICA includes:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cardiovascular diseases 

  • Project MONICA is related to cardiovascular diseases.
  • The WHO MONICA (MONItoring trends and determinants in CArdiovascular disease) Project was designed to measure trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease mortality and coronary heart disease and cerebrovascular disease morbidity, and to assess the extent to which these trends are related to changes in known risk factors

Ans. D. Proseal LMA

 

PROSEAL LMA

questions.text: In the context of the Indian health system, the NPCDCS was established with an objective to prevent and control major non-communicable diseases. An intern at a community health clinic is reviewing the diseases covered under this program to guide a health awareness session. Which of the following combinations best represents the conditions that fall under NPCDCS?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. CVD, Cancer, Diabetes, Stroke

 

NATIONAL PROGRAMME FOR PREVENTION & CONTROL OF DIABETES, CV DISEASES & STROKE (NPCDCS)

 

 

  • Through formation of NCD clinics, this was established in 100+ districts in India.
  • Set of 9 voluntary Global NCD targets for 2025 are:
    • Smoking and salt intake to be reduced by 30%.
    • Risk factors like alcohol and less physical activity to be reduced by 10%.
    • Reduction the premature deaths due to non-Communicable diseases by 25%.
    • Reduction in the prevalence of Hypertension by 25%.
    • >80% of the community must have access to affordable medicines for all NCDs in all private and public centers.
    • >50% of all patients must get access to drugs and medicines to prevent coronary artery disease or stroke.
    • Halt the epidemics of diabetes and obesity.

choices.text: Mean deviation

questions.text: In a recent health survey conducted in a diverse district near Pune, the health data collected exhibited a wide range of values, possibly due to the district's mix of urban, semi-urban, and rural populations. An epidemiologist working on the data set wants to effectively summarize this data by determining a measure of central tendency. Taking into account the variability in the values, which measure of central tendency would be most appropriate for the given set of data?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median

  • Central tendency is measured by median in case of a wide range of values as it is not affected by extremes of data.
  • On the other hand, mean the arithmetic average of all the values provided.
  • Hence, it can be affected by extremes of data whereas mode is the most frequently occurring value.

questions.text: A 38-year-old right handed school teacher who had been a competitive weight lifter for 18 years has been noticing parasthenia over the ulnar aspect of his right hand and progressive grip weakness. A clinical test was performed for the Right Hand weakness. What is the muscle and which peripheral nerve palsy is the cause for it?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adductor Pollicis; Ulnar Nerve

 

  • The above test is Froments sign test for Ulnar Nerve palsy, specifically testing the action of Adductor Pollicis. 
  • To perform this test, ask the patient to hold a piece of paper in between her thumb and index finger and attempt to pull the paper from the patients grip. 
  • A normal test is when the patient is able to maintain ahold of the paper. 
  • A positive test is when the patient compensates by flexing his Flexor Pollicis Longus to maintain his grip.
  • Other options are not correct for correct explanation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor Pollicis Brevis; Median Nerve: The Abductor Pollicis Brevis is innervated by the median nerve. Its weakness would lead to difficulty abducting the thumb, and not ulnar-sided paresthesia or the specific weakness as shown in the image.

 

Option C. Adductor Pollicis; Median Nerve: The Adductor Pollicis is innervated by the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve.

 

Option D. Abductor Pollicis Brevis; Ulnar Nerve: The Abductor Pollicis Brevis is innervated by the median nerve, not the ulnar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Adductor Pollicis muscle is responsible for adduction of the thumb. 
  • It is innervated by the ulnar nerve.
  • Weakness of this muscle, combined with ulnar paresthesia and general grip weakness, is highly indicative of ulnar nerve palsy. 
  • The test shown in the image is designed to elicit weakness of the Adductor Pollicis.

choices.text: Chronic gastritis due to Helicobacter pylori infection.
Peptic ulcer disease due to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of severe, recurrent peptic ulcers, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. He mentions that standard ulcer treatments have been ineffective. His medical history is notable for gastritis and weight loss. Laboratory tests reveal markedly elevated gastric acid levels, and an endoscopy shows multiple peptic ulcers in the stomach and duodenum. Further tests, including serum gastrin levels, are ordered to investigate the cause of his symptoms. Given the patient's symptoms and test results, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES)

  • This case presents a classic scenario for Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES), but let's break down each option to understand why:

Option A. Chronic gastritis due to Helicobacter pylori infection.

  • Helicobacter pylori is a common cause of chronic gastritis and peptic ulcers.
  • The typical presentation includes abdominal pain and discomfort, which can be relieved by standard ulcer treatments.
  • However, the markedly elevated gastric acid levels and severe, recurrent ulcers resistant to standard treatments in this patient are less typical of H. pylori infection, making this option less likely.

Option B. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

  • GERD is characterized by the backflow of stomach acids into the esophagus, leading to symptoms like heartburn, chest pain, and regurgitation.
  • While GERD can cause ulcers in the esophagus, it is less likely to cause multiple peptic ulcers in the stomach and duodenum, especially with the severe presentation seen in this case.

Option C. Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES).

  • ZES is characterized by one or more gastrin-secreting tumors (gastrinomas) that lead to excessive gastric acid production.
  • This results in severe, recurrent peptic ulcers often resistant to standard treatment, which matches the patient's presentation.
  • The markedly elevated gastric acid levels and the presence of multiple ulcers in both the stomach and duodenum strongly suggest ZES.

Option D. Peptic ulcer disease due to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use.

  • NSAIDs can cause peptic ulcer disease due to their mechanism of inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, which is protective for the gastric lining.
  • While NSAID use could explain peptic ulcers, it typically does not cause markedly elevated gastric acid levels or the severe, recurrent nature of ulcers as described in this patient.
  • Additionally, there's no mention of NSAID use in the patient's history.

choices.text: a, b, c
