questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD)?

 

  1. Testosterone > 2 ng/ml
  2. Infertility
  3. High FSH/LH ratio
  4. Fasting glucose/insulin ratio > 4.5
  5. Polycystic appearance on 1 or both ovaries on ultrasound
questions.solution:
Ans. C. a, b, e

  • PCOS includes chronic non ovulation, hyperandrogenism associated with normal or raised estradiol level (E2), raised LH & low FSH/LH ratio.
  • Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based upon the presence of any two of the following three criteria (Rotterdam Criteria):
  1. Oligomenorrhoea/or anovulation (Delayed cycles and infertility)
  2. Hyperandrogenism (Clinical &/or biochemical)
  3. Polycystic ovaries (Ultrasound finding of 1 OR both ovaries)
  • On investigation:
    • LH:FSH ratio is increased (3:1) i.e., LH is more than FSH
    • Increase free testosterone levels
    • Increase DHEAS
    • Fasting glucose: insulin ratio < 4.5
    • Sex hormone binding globulin decreases

 

Possible late sequelae of PCOD are:

  • Risk of developing diabetes mellitus (15%) due to insulin resistance.
  • Risk of developing endometrial carcinoma due to elevated level of estrogen.
  • Risk of hypertension & cardiovascular disease due w abnormal lipid profile (dyslipidemia).

 

Educational Objective:

  • On investigations in PCOS:
    • LH: FSH ratio is increased (3:1) i.e. LH is more than FSH
    • Increase free testosterone levels
    • Increase DHEAS
    • Fasting glucose: insulin ratio < 4.5
    • Sex hormone binding globulin decreases

 

 

Ref: Speroff’s clinical gynecological endocrinology and infertility, 9th edition, Page no. 411

choices.text: Black pigment stones
Brown pigment stones
Biliary sludge
Phospholipid stones

questions.text: A 50-year-old male film actor Sallu Kahn loses weight rap­idly for one of his forthcoming films. He experiences occa­sional abdominal discomfort few days after that and guided by his physician, he undergoes a radiological scan (HIDA scan) is shown to have slow and incomplete gallbladder emptying in response to cholecystokinin stimulation. This patient is likely to develop which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Biliary sludge

  • The demonstration of slow or incomplete gallbladder emp­tying in response to cholecystokinin stimulation is called gallbladder hypomotility. This is usually associated with risk factors like pregnancy, rapid weight loss prolonged use of total parenteral nutrition or octreotide, and high spinal cord injuries.
  • Gallbladder hypomotility frequently results in the forma­tion of biliary sludge, which results from bile precipitation. Biliary sludge typically contains cholesterol monohydrate crystals, calcium bilirubinate, and mucus and is a known precursor to stone formation. Complications such as acute cholecystitis occur in up to 20% of patients with biliary sludge.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Brown pigment stones are most likely to arise in cases of biliary tract infection.

 

Option A. Black pigment stones are most likely to arise in cases of intravascular hemolysis.

 

Option D. Phospholipid stones. Gallstones do not typically contain phospho­lipid as a primary ingredient.

 

 

Ref: Robbins, 10thedition, page no. 871

choices.text: Post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis

questions.text: In a 45-year-old male patient from Bihar with a normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesion and a history of prolonged fever in childhood, what is the probable clinical diagnosis, considering the absence of thickened nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis

 

Explanation of each option:

 

Option D. Post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis.

  • The case scenario suggests a diagnosis of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis.
  • Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis:
    • Occurs 1-5 years after Kala azar in untreated or incompletely treated cases. Manifests as nodules over exposed areas (Face), Hypopigmented macules over trunk and photosensitivity.
    • The rash is progressive over many years and seldom heals spontaneously.

  • Important differential for PKDL is Lepromatous leprosy:

  • Drug of choice for:
    • Kala azar: Liposomal Amphotericin B
    • PKDL: Miltefosine

Option A. Tuberculoid leprosy.

  • This form of leprosy presents with hypopigmented patches with well-defined borders.
  • However, it is typically associated with thickened nerves, which is absent in the patient described.

Option B. Lepromatous leprosy.

  • This is a more advanced and disseminated form of leprosy with multiple nodules, plaques, and thickened nerves.
  • It doesn't fit the presentation described.

Option C. Mycosis fungoides.

  • It is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.
  • The initial presentation can be patches, which might resemble the described lesions, but the history of prolonged fever in childhood and the geographic location (Bihar) make PKDL more probable.

Educational objective:

  • Identify PKDL as a probable diagnosis in a patient with a history of prolonged fever in childhood presenting with normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesions without any thickened nerves, especially from the Bihar region.

 

 

Ref: Rook’s textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition, Page no. 33.50-33.51, 140.10

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother, who is concerned about the appearance of her son's teeth. She first noticed white patches on his anterior incisors several months ago. However, recently, these patches have turned a distinct brown color. She is worried about any potential harm to her child's health and is curious about the cause of these discolorations. Out of the below mentioned elements, which one is most likely responsible for this discoloration?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fluorine

  • Dental fluorosis occurs when excess fluoride is ingested during first 7 years of life (years of tooth calcification).
  • It occurs at levels above 1.5 mg/litre intake.
  • It is characterized by ’Mottling’, which is best seen on incisors of upper jaw. 
  • Definition of Suspect case of Dental Fluorosis (in children): Any case with a history of residing in an endemic area along with one or both of the followings:
    • Chalky white teeth/white spots on the white enamel surface
    • Transverse yellow, brown/black bands or spots on the enamel surface

 

  • Ideally, in water, there should be 0.5 to 0.8 mg/l of fluorine (India). The major source of fluorine in human is Drinking water.
  • Fluorine is a double-edged sword. 
  • Dental Fluorosis occurs when Fluorine level is >0.8mg/l in water. In that case, the water should be defluoridated using Nalgonda technique. 
  • If the level of fluorine is <0.5mg/l, then the fluorine deficiency will lead to Dental Caries. In that case, fluorine supplementation should be done.
    • Level > 1.5 ppm: Dental fluorosis (mottling)
    • Level 3.0-6.0 ppm: Skeletal fluorosis
    • Level > 10.0 ppm: Crippling fluorosis
       
  • Fluorosis endemic area: Habitation/village/town having fluoride level >1.5 ppm in drinking water
  • Villages classification based on the level of fluoride content:

choices.text: Lymphatics from scrotum drain into internal iliac nodes.
Anterior third of the scrotum is supplied by ilioinguinal and genitofemoral nerves.
Layers of the scrotum from outer to inner are skin, dartos, external spermatic fascia, internal spermatic fascia, cremaster, parietal layer of tunica vaginalis.
Right half of the scrotum is lower than the left side.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was brought to ER with complaints of right sided scrotal pain and swelling that gradually worsened over the past 5 days. He complained of raised body temperature and chills. On examination, his right hemiscrotum is warm, tender and erythematous. Cremasteric reflex is present. Scrotal ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis of scrotal abscess. Which of the following statements pertaining to the above case is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Anterior third of the scrotum is supplied by ilioinguinal and genitofemoral nerves.

  • Lymphatics from scrotum drain into superficial inguinal nodes.
  • Anterior third of the scrotum is supplied by ilioinguinal and genitofemoral nerves, posterior two third is supplied by scrotal branches of pudendal nerve.
  • Layers of the scrotum from outer to inner are skin, dartos, external spermatic fascia, cremaster, internal spermatic fascia, parietal layer of tunica vaginalis.
  • Left half of the scrotum is lower than the right side for accommodation of elongated left spermatic cord.

 

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy, 41st edition, page no. 1286

questions.text: A 21-year-old male came to OPD with complaints of easy bruising and prolonged bleeding from minor cuts. His laboratory investigations reveal prolonged prothrombin time. The physician prescribed him vitamin K supplementation, after which her condition improved. Vitamin K is required for activation of clotting factors:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2, 7, 9, 10

  • Vitamin K is required for activation of clotting factors 2, 7, 9 and 10 by post translational modification.
  • It facilitates y-carboxylation of the glutamate amino acids in these clotting factors which facilitates clotting.

 

 

 

  • Vitamin K is also required for Y-carboxylation of osteocalcin and protein C and S involved in blood clotting.

questions.text: A 39-year-old female presents to the clinic with episodic headaches, palpitations, and sweating for the past six months. These episodes are random and are sometimes accompanied by a sense of anxiety and tremors. Her blood pressure during these episodes reaches up to 180/110 mmHg, but it normalizes afterwards. She has no significant past medical history and her family history is unremarkable. A 24-hour urinary collection reveals elevated levels of metanephrines and normetanephrines. Based on the patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pheochromocytoma

  • Pheochromocytoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that typically arises from the adrenal medulla, producing excessive catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine).
  • This leads to episodic symptoms like headaches, palpitations, sweating, hypertension, and anxiety, aligning with the patient's presentation.
  • The diagnosis is further supported by the elevated urinary levels of metanephrines and normetanephrines, which are metabolites of catecholamines.
  • Generalized anxiety disorder could explain some symptoms like palpitations and anxiety, but it would not account for the hypertension or the elevated catecholamine metabolites.
  • Hyperthyroidism may present with palpitations and tremors, but it typically does not cause episodic hypertension.
  • Essential hypertension is usually persistent, not episodic, and does not cause elevated catecholamine metabolites.

choices.text: Right middle lobe consolidation
Right lower lobe consolidation
Right pleural effusion

questions.text: A 39-year-old patient presents with high grade fever, chills and cough with copious production of purulent sputum. An X-ray examination was made as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Right middle lobe consolidation

 

RIGHT MIDDLE LOBE CONSOLIDATION

  • The X-ray image shows an area of increased opacity in the right middle lobe of the lung silhouetting the right heart border which is indicative of consolidation.
  • This finding, along with the patient's clinical symptoms of high-grade fever, chills, and copious purulent sputum production, is highly suggestive of a bacterial lung infection.
  • Silhouette sign:
    • The outline of a specific structure that is created at the boundary between two tissues with varying tissue densities is called a silhouette in a chest radiograph, for example, the cardiac silhouette between the heart and the lung.
    • The silhouette sign is the blurring or obliteration of these typical silhouettes brought on by disease pathologies.

  • When the markings of heart are not visible – silhouette sign positive – localised to middle lobe/lingula
  • When the markings of heart are visible – silhouette sign negative – localised to lower lobe

choices.text: Kleihauer Betke test

questions.text: A 32-year Rh negative woman had a normal delivery following which the following test was done. What is this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Kleihauer Betke test

 

Tests for feto-maternal haemorrhage are:

  1. Rosette test (Qualitative estimation)
  2. Kleihauer Betke test (acid elution test)
  3. Flow cytometry
  • The test shown here is the Kleihauer Betke test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tests for feto-maternal haemorrhage are:

      1.  

1. Rosette test (Qualitative estimation)

2. Kleihauer Betke test (acid elution test)

3. Flow cytometry

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no. 307

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with weight loss, fatigue, and night sweats. He also reports a persistent dry cough and occasional shortness of breath. On physical examination, he has mild splenomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal mild anemia, and a serum protein electrophoresis shows a small monoclonal spike in the gamma region. Immunofixation electrophoresis identifies the presence of monoclonal gamma heavy chains without associated light chains. A lymph node biopsy is suggestive of lymphoplasmacytic infiltration. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Franklin's Disease

  • Franklin's Disease, or Gamma Heavy Chain Disease, is a rare disorder characterized by the production of abnormal gamma heavy chains.
  • The typical presentation includes symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and often respiratory symptoms due to lymphoid infiltration of the lungs, aligning with this patient's symptoms.
  • The presence of monoclonal gamma heavy chains without associated light chains, as identified by immunofixation electrophoresis, is a key laboratory finding for Franklin's Disease.
  • Multiple Myeloma generally shows a monoclonal spike with both heavy and light chains and is often associated with bone lesions and renal impairment.
  • Waldenström Macroglobulinemia involves IgM heavy chains and presents with different clinical features.
  • Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma is a broad category of lymphoid cancers but would not typically present with the monoclonal gamma heavy chain without light chains.

Other options:

 

Option A. Multiple Myeloma.

  • Multiple Myeloma is a hematological malignancy characterized by the proliferation of plasma cells in the bone marrow.
  • It typically presents with anemia, renal insufficiency, hypercalcemia, and bone lesions (often described as lytic lesions).
  • In serum protein electrophoresis, multiple myeloma usually shows a large monoclonal spike, and immunofixation often reveals the presence of monoclonal heavy and light chains.
  • The absence of significant bone pain or renal impairment and the presence of monoclonal gamma heavy chains without light chains are less typical for multiple myeloma.

Option B. Waldenström Macroglobulinemia.

  • Waldenström Macroglobulinemia is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by the overproduction of monoclonal IgM immunoglobulins.
  • Patients often present with symptoms related to hyperviscosity, such as bleeding, visual disturbances, and neurological symptoms.
  • Laboratory findings include an IgM monoclonal spike on serum protein electrophoresis.
  • The immunofixation in this case does not indicate IgM heavy chains, making this diagnosis less likely.

Option D. Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma.

  • Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (NHL) is a diverse group of blood cancers that includes many different types of lymphoma.
  • While NHL can present with symptoms like weight loss, night sweats, and splenomegaly, the specific finding of monoclonal gamma heavy chains without light chains seen in this patient is not typical for most forms of NHL.
  • NHL often presents with a variety of other histopathological and immunophenotypic findings.

choices.text: Decreased blood flow
Exposure to sunlight
Increased blood flow

questions.text: A 55 years old male who is a chronic alcoholic develops a clinical condition as shown in the picture. It is characterized by formation and deposition of sodium urate crystals in the joints of the extremities. Which of the following factors contributes to the formation of urate crystals?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Decreased temperature

  • Hyperuricemia (gout) is a clinical condition characterized by elevated levels of uric acid that lead to the formation of sodium urate crystals.
  • Uric acid has a pKa of 5.4 and is ionized in the body to form urate, which is not very soluble in an aqueous environment and the quantity of urate in human blood is also very close to the solubility range.
  • So, any situations which leads to excessive degradation of purine bases can increase the urate concentration past the solubility point causing formation of urate crystals.
  • The decreased body temperature seen in the joints contributes to the formation of urate crystals under these conditions.  

Incorrect answers:

 

Option B. Decreased blood flow; Option C. Exposure to sunlight and Option D. Increased blood flow. Does not contribute to the formation of urate crystals.

questions.text: Functional deficiency of which hormone causes preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Progesterone

  • Progesterone is the main hormone supporting pregnancy.
  • A functional deficiency leads to the onset of labor.

 

Educational Objective:

  • A functional deficiency of progesterone is one of the theories behind onset of labor.

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no. 810

choices.text: Reverse Cozen’s Test

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presented in OPD with complaints of pain in wrist around Radial styloid with difficulty in performing activities of daily living. What is the clinical test demonstrated below to diagnose this condition is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Finkelstein’s Test

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option B. Finkelstein's Test. This test is specifically used to diagnose De Quervain's tenosynovitis. During the test, the patient makes a fist with the thumb inside the fingers, and the wrist is ulnarly deviated. The examiner then stabilizes the patient's forearm, and the patient is asked to move the wrist into radial deviation. A positive test result is indicated by pain over the radial styloid, which suggests inflammation of the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis, characteristic of De Quervain's tenosynovitis.

 

Option A. Cozen's Test. Cozen's test is used to assess lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow) and involves resisted wrist extension with the elbow extended and the wrist in pronation. It is not related to De Quervain's tenosynovitis.

 

 

Option C. Reverse Cozen's Test. "Reverse Cozen's Test" is not a recognized clinical test. It is not related to either De Quervain's tenosynovitis or any other specific condition.

 

Option D. Phalen's Test. Phalen's test is used to assess carpal tunnel syndrome and involves flexing the wrist and holding it in a flexed position for a minute to reproduce symptoms. It is not specific to De Quervain's tenosynovitis.

choices.text: Increased risk of abortion

questions.text: All are effects of hypothyroidism on pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Placenta previa

 

Maternal and Fetal Effects of Hypothyroidism:

 

 

 

  • Hypothyroidism is not a risk factor for Placenta previa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no. 270

choices.text: Superior laryngeal nerve injury
Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury
Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient started having difficulty in breathing, and repeated attempts to extubate were unsuccessful. The most probable cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

  • In the scenario described, a patient who has undergone total thyroidectomy is experiencing difficulty in breathing, with unsuccessful extubation attempts.

Analysis of given options:

 

Option A. Superior Laryngeal Nerve Injury.

  • The superior laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve, innervates the cricothyroid muscle and provides sensation to the larynx above the vocal cords.
  • Injury to this nerve typically results in voice changes, such as a weak or hoarse voice, because it affects the tension of the vocal cords.
  • However, it is less likely to cause significant breathing difficulties, as it does not directly affect the opening of the vocal cords.

Option B. Unilateral Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve Injury.

  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates most of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, crucial for voice production and breathing.
  • Injury to this nerve on one side (unilaterally) often leads to hoarseness or a change in voice, as one vocal cord may become paralyzed or weakened.
  • Typically, unilateral injury does not cause significant breathing difficulty because the unaffected side can still maintain an open airway.

Option C. Bilateral Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve Injury.

  • Injury to both recurrent laryngeal nerves (bilaterally) is a more severe condition.
  • Vocal cords cannot be abducted and thus come to lie in a median or paramedian position due to unopposed action of cricothyroid. This results in compromised laryngeal airway causing respiratory distress and stridor.
  • This condition can lead to significant breathing difficulties, stridor (a high-pitched wheezing sound), and can be life-threatening, often necessitating urgent airway management.
  • Tracheostomy is done as an emergency procedure to secure the airway.
  • Widening the respiratory airway without a permanent tracheostomy can be achieved by:
    • Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)
    • Partial arytenoidectomy
    • Reinnervation procedures: these are used to innervate paralyzed posterior cricoarytenoid muscle by implanting a nerve-muscle pedicle of sternohyoid or omohyoid muscle with its nerve supply from ansa hypoglossi.
    • Thyroplasty type II: lateralisation of vocal cords

 

Option D. Hematoma.

  • A hematoma is a collection of blood outside of blood vessels, which can occur as a complication of thyroid surgery.
  • If significant, a hematoma in the neck can rapidly expand and compress the trachea, leading to acute airway obstruction.
  • This condition presents with swelling in the neck, pain, and breathing difficulty, and is a surgical emergency.

Considering these explanations, the most likely cause of the breathing difficulty and unsuccessful extubation attempts in a post-thyroidectomy patient is either bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury or a rapidly expanding hematoma, with the former being more likely if the symptoms are purely respiratory without external neck swelling or pain.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Understand and differentiate the clinical implications of superior laryngeal nerve injury, unilateral and bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injuries, and hematoma as complications following total thyroidectomy, with a focus on their impact on voice and breathing.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male who is a known hypertensive is posted for laparoscopic appendicectomy under general anesthesia. Post the surgery his serum creatinine goes up to 4.5 and he has kidney failure. What could be the causative inhalational agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Methoxyflurane

  • Methoxyflurane is the most nephrotoxic inhalational agent as it produces a large amount of inorganic fluorides causing polyuric renal failure.
  • Least nephrotoxic is desflurane.

choices.text: Chronic kidney disease secondary to hypertension

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a long-standing history of alcoholic liver disease presents with progressive abdominal distension and jaundice. He has a history of esophageal varices and ascites. On examination, his blood pressure is low, and he is tachycardic. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes, hyperbilirubinemia, and a significant increase in serum creatinine from baseline. Urinalysis shows a low sodium concentration without significant proteinuria or hematuria. An abdominal ultrasound rules out any obstructive uropathy. Based on the patient's history and clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hepatorenal syndrome

  • Hepatorenal syndrome is a form of kidney failure occurring in individuals with advanced liver disease, often characterized by cirrhosis and portal hypertension, as seen in this patient.
  • Key features include worsening renal function without intrinsic kidney damage, as indicated by the absence of significant findings on urinalysis and ultrasound.
  • The patient's low blood pressure and tachycardia may suggest a prerenal component, but in the context of severe liver disease and the absence of other causes of acute kidney injury, hepatorenal syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.
  • Acute interstitial nephritis and chronic kidney disease due to hypertension would typically present with different clinical and laboratory findings.

questions.text: A patient with a history of severe asthma is scheduled for an appendectomy. Which of the following induction agents will cause the least respiratory depression?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ketamine

  • In a patient with a history of severe asthma scheduled for surgery, it is important to choose an induction agent that causes the least respiratory depression to minimize the risk of exacerbating asthma symptoms.

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option A. Ketamine. Ketamine is known for its bronchodilator properties and minimal respiratory depression. It can actually stimulate the respiratory drive and maintain airway reflexes, making it a suitable choice for patients with asthma. Ketamine is often preferred for induction in patients with bronchospastic diseases like asthma.

 

Option B. Propofol. Propofol is a commonly used induction agent, but it can cause respiratory depression. It is not the best choice for a patient with a history of severe asthma as it may further suppress respiratory function.

 

Option C. Etomidate. Etomidate is generally considered a good choice for induction in patients with compromised respiratory function because it has a relatively mild impact on respiration. However, ketamine is still a better choice for asthma patients due to its bronchodilatory effects.

 

Option D. Thiopental. Thiopental, like propofol, can cause respiratory depression and is not the ideal choice for a patient with a history of severe asthma.

 

Educational objective:

  • Ketamine is the most suitable induction agent for a patient with severe asthma because it has bronchodilator properties and causes minimal respiratory depression, making it less likely to exacerbate asthma symptoms during induction.

choices.text: Cumulative incidence
Relative risk

questions.text: Dr. Aravind, a diligent researcher from Hyderabad, embarks on a longitudinal study evaluating the emergence of a novel infectious disease in a specific region. Over the course of the study, he notices that more people in the community start manifesting symptoms of the disease as time progresses. During a discussion with his team, he uses a term to describe the increased risk of the disease in the population over a specified time frame. Which of the following terms most accurately captures the essence of his observation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cumulative incidence

  • The Cumulative incidence is calculated as the number of new events or cases of disease divided by the total number of individuals in the population at risk for a specific time interval.
  • Researchers can use cumulative incidence to predict risk of a disease or event over periods of time.
  • Cumulative incidence measures denominator ‘only at the beginning of the study’.

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Incidence is defined as the ‘no. of new cases’ occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time. Incidence is a RATE, expressed per 1000. Incidence is the best measure of disease frequency in etiological studies. Incidence can be determined from Cohort study. 

 

Option C. Prevalence is total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over a point or period of time. PREVALENCE IS A PROPORTION (Prevalence IS NOT A RATIO). Prevalence can be determined from Cross-Sectional Study. 

 

Option D. Relative risk. Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by Relative risk (RR), Attributable risk (AR), Population attributable risk (PAR). 

 

Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/Incidence among non-exposed

 

RR = Iexposed/Inon-exposed

questions.text: A 35 years old healthy male is presented with a gunshot wound to right upper thigh region. On examination, patient was hemodynamically stable but had no palpable lower extremity pulses on the injured side. On exploration, superficial femoral artery was transected. Which of the following is the suture material to be used for vascular repair?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Polypropylene

  • Polypropylene (Proline) suture is a monofilament non absorbable suture.
  • It comprises of isotactic crystalline stereoisomer of polypropylene.
  • It is blue in colour to enhance visibility.
  • It elicits maximum tensile strength and minimal tissue reaction that does not cause tissue rupture.
  • It is preferred suture material for vascular anastomoses. It is neither absorbed not subjected to weakening by tissue enzymes, non-adhering, and biologically inert. Thus, it is used for permanent fixtures.
  • Other uses are general soft tissue approximation and ligation in cardiovascular, plastic, neurological surgeries and hernia repair.

Other options:

 

Option A. Polyglactin (Vicryl) is a synthetic absorbable sterile suture. Copolymer of 90% glycol and 10% l-lactide. It retrains tensile strength of about 70% till 14 days after implantation, it is completely absorbed within 56-70 days by simple hydrolysis.

 

Option B. Polydioxanone (PDS) is a synthetic absorbable sterile suture composed of polyester - p – dioxanone.  It is suitable for cases where extended would support and strength are required. It retains about 70% of initial strength for 2 weeks, 50% for 4 weeks and 25% for 6 weeks and is absorbed through simple hydrolysis and completely absorbed within 180-210 days.

  • Delayed absorbable sutures like Vicryl and PDS are preferred for biliary and urological anastomosis where there is risk of foreign body inflammation and stone formation.
  • Vicryl is also known as work-horse suture of general surgery.

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Edition, page no. 105-106

choices.text: Glutathione peroxidase
NADPH oxidase
Superoxide dismutase

questions.text: Reactive oxygen intermediates are released by:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. NADPH oxidase

  • NADPH oxidase is an enzyme complex found in the membranes of certain cells, such as phagocytes (neutrophils, macrophages) and B cells.
  • It plays a crucial role in the immune response by producing superoxide anion (O2−), a reactive oxygen intermediate, from molecular oxygen (O2) using NADPH as the electron donor.
  • This superoxide can then spontaneously or enzymatically dismutate into hydrogen peroxide, which can be further converted into other reactive species or used in the oxidative burst in immune cells to kill invading pathogens.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Catalase is an enzyme that catalyzes the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen. While it is involved in the removal of reactive oxygen species (ROS), it does not release reactive oxygen intermediates; instead, it participates in their detoxification.

 

Option B. Glutathione peroxidase is an enzyme that plays a role in the protection of cells from oxidative damage by reducing lipid hydroperoxides and hydrogen peroxide. It does not release reactive oxygen intermediates but instead acts to neutralize them.

 

Option D. Superoxide dismutase. SOD is an enzyme that catalyzes the dismutation of superoxide radicals into oxygen and hydrogen peroxide. It doesn't release reactive oxygen intermediates but rather acts to convert one reactive oxygen intermediate (superoxide) into another (hydrogen peroxide), which can then be further detoxified by other enzymes like catalase and glutathione peroxidase.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of congestive heart failure presents to the emergency room with decreased urine output and fatigue. He reports that he has been feeling increasingly breathless over the past week and has not been taking his diuretics regularly. On examination, he has bilateral ankle edema, and his blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. Blood tests show an elevated serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) with a BUN to creatinine ratio greater than 20:1. Urinalysis shows low urine sodium and high urine osmolality. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pre-Renal Azotemia

  • This patient's presentation is indicative of pre-renal azotemia, commonly associated with conditions leading to decreased renal perfusion.
  • In this case, the history of congestive heart failure, not taking diuretics regularly, hypotension, and the lab findings (elevated BUN and creatinine with a high BUN to creatinine ratio, low urine sodium, and high urine osmolality) are consistent with decreased renal blood flow leading to reduced glomerular filtration.

Other options:

 

Option A. Acute Tubular Necrosis. Generally, presents with a history of recent severe illness, drug toxicity, or ischemia. Urinalysis in ATN typically shows muddy brown casts, which are not mentioned here.

 

Option C. Chronic Kidney Disease. Characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time. This scenario seems more acute in nature and is associated with specific circumstances (heart failure, hypotension) pointing towards pre-renal causes.

 

Option D. Post-Renal Obstruction. Typically presents with symptoms of urinary tract obstruction such as flank pain or difficulty urinating, which are not described in this case.

  • The combination of clinical history, physical examination findings, and laboratory results strongly suggests pre-renal azotemia as the most likely diagnosis.Top of Form

choices.text: Slow filling at end of diastole
End of systole
Start of diastole

questions.text: 'c' wave in JVP is seen in which phase of cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Iso-volumetric contraction

  • 'c' waves are produced by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during the Iso-volumetric contraction of the right ventricle.

 

Fig: Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v = Positive wave; x, x1, y = Negative waves

questions.text: The transport of urea in the collecting duct will be mediated by which of these transporters?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. UT-A1, UT-A3

  • The transport of urea in the renal tubules will be mediated by urea transporters, mostly by facilitated diffusion (passive transport).
  • There are two major types of urea transporters: UT-A and UT-B.
  • The urea transport protein UT-A has 4 isoforms in the kidneys (from UT-A1 to UT-A 4).
  • The transport of urea in the collecting ducts of the kidneys will be mediated by the transporters, UT-A1 and UT-A3.

 

 

Ref: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, page no. 686

choices.text: The external opening is in upper half of anterior SCM muscle
The internal opening is in front of posterior tonsillar pillar
The tract passes above carotid artery bifurcation
Treat is complete excision of the tract

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about branchial fistula?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The external opening is in upper half of anterior SCM muscle

  • A branchial fistula may be unilateral or bilateral and is thought to represent a persistent second branchial cleft.
  • The external orifice is nearly always situated in the lower third of the neck near the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, while the internal orifice is located on the anterior aspect of the posterior facial pillar just behind the tonsil.
  •  Although the anterior aspect of the tract is easy to dissect, it may pass backwards and upwards through the bifurcation of the common carotid artery.
  • The tract is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium and, as such, there may be a small amount of recurrent mucopurulent discharge onto the neck.
  • The tract follows the same path as a branchial cyst and requires complete excision to avoid recurrence.
  • A branchial cyst develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft, is lined by squamous epithelium and contains thick, turbid fluid.
  • The cyst usually presents in the upper neck in early or middle adulthood and is found at the junction of the upper third and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border. It is a fluctuant swelling that may transilluminate.
  • Ultrasound and fine-needle aspiration aid both diagnosis and treatment by complete excision.

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Edition, Page no. 805

questions.text: Drug used in irritable bowel syndrome with constipation is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lubiprostone

  • The drug used in irritable bowel syndrome with constipation is Lubiprostone, which is a type of chloride channel activator. It works by increasing the secretion of chloride ions into the intestinal lumen, leading to increased fluid secretion and improved gastrointestinal motility. This helps in relieving constipation and other symptoms associated with irritable bowel syndrome.
  • Loperamide is an anti-diarrheal medication and is not effective in treating constipation.
  • Alosetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist used for the treatment of irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea.
  • Clonidine is an alpha-2 agonist used in the management of hypertension and diabetic diarrhea.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of weakness in his right arm after using crutches for six weeks due to a leg fracture. He mentions that the crutches were possibly too tall for him, as they pressed hard into his armpit. On examination, there is a notable deficit in the extension of his wrist and fingers. His sense of touch is diminished over the posterior aspect of his arm and forearm and the dorsum of his hand. Given the distribution of his symptoms, which structure is most likely to be affected by the prolonged use of crutches?
questions.solution:
Ans. A.  Posterior cord

  • This is the case of crutch palsy.
  • In Crutch palsy, the nerve injured is the radial nerve.
  • The radial nerve is a branch of the posterior cord.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Lateral cord: The lateral cord gives rise to nerves that supply the anterior compartment of the arm and hand, not responsible for extension or the sensory pattern described, so compression here would not produce these symptoms.

 

Option C. Medial cord: The medial cord contributes mainly to nerves innervating the medial side of the forearm and hand, not the dorsal aspect or extensors.

 

Option D. Upper trunk: Injury to the upper trunk typically manifests as Erb's palsy pattern, affecting shoulder abduction and elbow flexion, rather than the wrist and finger extensors or the described sensory loss.
 

Educational Objective:

Prolonged axillary pressure from crutches can injure the posterior cord of the brachial plexus, resulting in radial nerve palsy (wrist drop and sensory loss over the posterior arm, forearm, and hand dorsum).

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram singh, page no. 47

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who is breastfeeding her 2-month-old infant presents to the clinic with a painful, red, and swollen lump in her right breast. She reports having a fever and feeling unwell for the past 24 hours. On examination, there is a tender, fluctuant mass in the upper outer quadrant of breast. What will be the next best investigation to evaluate this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. USG

 

In this case, ultrasound (USG) is the most appropriate initial imaging investigation for several reasons:

  • USG can help differentiate between an abscess (a fluid-filled cavity, which is a possible complication of mastitis) and other breast conditions.
  • It is a safe and non-invasive imaging method that does not involve ionizing radiation, making it suitable for breastfeeding women and young individuals.
  • USG can provide real-time imaging and can guide procedures such as fine-needle aspiration or drainage of an abscess if necessary.

Option A. Mammograms are more suitable for breast imaging in older women or when there is a suspicion of breast cancer.

 

Option B. Breast MRI is typically reserved for specific indications, such as evaluating breast cancer extent or assessing breast implants. It is not the initial investigation for a patient with a painful, red, and swollen lump suggestive of mastitis.

 

Option D: CT imaging is generally not the first-line choice for breast evaluation, especially in young women and when the clinical presentation is consistent with mastitis. It exposes the patient to ionizing radiation, which should be minimized, particularly in breast imaging.

questions.text: Which item below does not qualify as personal protective equipment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lab coat

 

A lab coat is not a personal protective equipment.

 

Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) are:

Gloves: protect hands

Gowns/aprons: protect skin and clothing

Masks protect the mouth/nose and respirators protect the respiratory tract from airborne infectious agents

Goggles: protect eyes

Face shields: protect face, mouth, nose, and eyes

choices.text: Lower limb venography

questions.text: A person comes with fracture tibia with swelling of lower leg pulse feeble but palpable. Intacompatmental pressure is raised. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fasciotomy

 

Explanation for each option:

 

Option A. Fasciotomy. In cases of tibia fractures associated with swelling, a compromised vascular supply, and elevated compartment pressure, there is a risk of compartment syndrome. Compartment syndrome occurs when increased pressure within a closed anatomical compartment (such as the leg) impairs blood flow, potentially leading to tissue ischemia and necrosis. A feeble but palpable pulse is an indication that blood flow is compromised. The definitive treatment for compartment syndrome is fasciotomy, which involves making a surgical incision to relieve pressure within the affected compartment, thereby restoring blood flow and preventing tissue damage.

 

Option B. External fixation. External fixation may be considered in certain cases, but it does not address the issue of compartment syndrome directly. It is typically used to stabilize the fracture temporarily and may not relieve the pressure within the compartment.

 

Option C. Interlock nail. Intramedullary nailing (interlock nail) is a surgical technique used to stabilize the fractured bone but does not directly address compartment syndrome or elevated compartment pressures.

 

Option D. Lower limb venography. Lower limb venography is not the primary diagnostic or therapeutic option for compartment syndrome. It is used to evaluate the venous system and is not indicated in the acute management of a tibia fracture with signs of compartment syndrome.

choices.text: Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy

questions.text: Identify the feeding technique using this tube.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy

  • A PEG involves the insertion of the gastrostomy tube through the abdomen and stomach under vision via an endoscope, avoiding a surgical incision and a general anesthetic. The endoscopist is able to visualize a cannula entering the insufflated stomach via the anterior abdominal wall, through which a guidewire is passed.
  • Then either the gastrostomy tube can be inserted through the anterior abdominal wall over the guidewire or the guidewire can be pulled out via the mouth and the tube secured to the guidewire, pulled down into the stomach and then pulled out through the abdominal wall.
  • The stomach wall is pulled up to the anterior abdominal wall and held in place by a cuff, balloon or plastic bumper to minimise the risk of intraperitoneal leakage.

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Edition, Page no. 336-337

On abdominal examination, there is sub-umbilical flattening and the fetal heart is auscultated on the flanks. The most likely kind of pelvis is:

questions.text: In which condition is excessive urinary excretion of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5HIAA) seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Carcinoid syndrome

  • 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5HIAA) is a metabolite of serotonin, a neurotransmitter that is produced in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • In normal circumstances, most of the serotonin produced in the enterochromaffin cells is metabolized in the liver and then excreted in the urine as 5HIAA.
  • However, in carcinoid syndrome, serotonin-secreting tumors can produce excessive amounts of serotonin that overwhelm the metabolic capacity of the liver, resulting in high levels of urinary 5HIAA.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Alkaptonuria is a rare genetic disorder in which homogentisic acid is not properly metabolized, leading to its accumulation in various tissues and the urine. This condition is not related to serotonin metabolism.

 

Option B. Albinism is a genetic disorder that results in reduced or absent production of melanin, the pigment that gives color to the skin, hair, and eyes. This condition is also not related to serotonin metabolism.

 

Option D. Phenylketonuria is an inherited metabolic disorder in which the body cannot properly process the amino acid phenylalanine. This results in the accumulation of toxic byproducts that can lead to intellectual disability, seizures, and other serious health problems. This condition is also not related to serotonin metabolism.

questions.text: The deepest part of the perineal body, if cut/damaged can lead to rectocele, cystocele and uterine prolapse. This is due to damage of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pubococcygeus

  • Weakness of the pubococcygeus and iliococcygeus muscles cause the elevator plate to sag and cause prolapse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ischiocavernosus. Weakness of the ischiocavernosus causes sexual dysfunction.

 

Option B. Bulbocavernosus. Weakness of the bulbocavernosus also causes sexual dysfunction.

 

Option D. External anal sphincter. Weakness of the external anal sphincter can lead to anal incontinence.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Weakness of the pubococcygeus and iliococcygeus muscles cause the elevator plate to sag and cause prolapse.

 

Ref: Berek & Novak’s Gynecology, 16th edition, e-book, page no. 1616, 1642

choices.text: Kata thermometer
Wet globe thermometer

questions.text: Which one of the provided thermometers is employed for measuring low air velocity as opposed to the cooling potency of the air?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Kata thermometer 

  • Kata thermometer is used to measure low air velocity rather than the cooling power of the air.
  • It works by measuring the temperature difference between two thin wires heated to different temperatures in a moving air stream.
  • The faster the air moves, the greater the temperature difference between the two wires, allowing the Kata thermometer to measure air velocity.

questions.text: All of the following methods are used for the diagnosis of HIV infection in a 2 months old child, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HIV ELISA

 

  • HIV ELISA is required for detection of antibodies against the virus.

  • The antibodies may be present in the infant because of maternal infection also because IgG antibodies can cross the placental barrier.

  • So, the presence of anti HIV antibodies is not reliable for diagnosis of HIV in a 2 month old child.

  • Please dont get foxed by the option viral culture friends.

  • There is indeed a HIV culture method being used which is called as peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) using the virus microculture in macrophages concept.

  • PBMC are drawn in high concentration from centrifugation of freshly drawn anticoagulated venous blood.

  • Viral DNA detection using DNA-PCR and p24 antigen assay are standard techniques used for viral detection.

choices.text: It is slower acting than clopidogrel.
It is contraindicated in stroke.
It is a reversible antagonist of ADP receptors.
Decrease the risk of bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about prasugrel is true as compared to clopidogrel?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is contraindicated in stroke.

  • Prasugrel is an antiplatelet drug that inhibits ADP-mediated platelet activation and aggregation by irreversibly binding to P2Y12 receptors on platelets. It is a thienopyridine that is converted to its active metabolite more rapidly than clopidogrel, leading to more potent and rapid platelet inhibition. Therefore, option A is incorrect.
  • Prasugrel is indicated for the treatment of acute coronary syndromes (ACS) and in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). However, it is contraindicated in patients with a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA) due to an increased risk of bleeding. Therefore, option B is the correct answer.
  • Both prasugrel and clopidogrel irreversibly bind to P2Y12 receptors on platelets, making them irreversible antagonists. Therefore, option C is incorrect.
  • Prasugrel has been associated with an increased risk of bleeding compared to clopidogrel, especially in patients with a history of stroke or TIA. Therefore, option D is also incorrect.

choices.text: Retinoic acid
Pantothenic acid

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of delayed adaptation to vision in dark places, gritty sensation in the eyes, dry eyes, and softening of the cornea. What is the likely deficiency in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Retinoic acid

  • The clinical history is suggestive of vitamin A/Retinoic acid deficiency.
  • Bright light depletes stores of rhodopsin in rods.
  • Therefore, when a person shifts suddenly from bright light to a dimly lit area, there is difficulty in seeing, for example, entering a cinema theater.
  • After a few minutes, rhodopsin is resynthesized and vision is improved. This period is called dark adaptation time. It is increased in vitamin A deficiency.

  • Ocular Manifestations of Vitamin A deficiency:

a. Night blindness: Visual acuity is diminished in dim light. The patient cannot read or drive a car in poor light. The dark adaptation time is increased.

 

b. Xerophthalmia: The conjunctiva becomes dry, thick and wrinkled. The conjunctiva gets keratinized and loses its normal transparency. Dryness spreads to cornea. It becomes glazy and lusterless due to keratinization of corneal epithelium. Infections may supersede.

 

c. Bitot's Spots: These are seen as grayish-white triangular plaques firmly adherent to the conjunctiva. This is due to increased thickness of conjunctiva in certain areas. All the ocular changes mentioned so far are completely reversible when vitamin is supplemented.

 

 

 

d. Keratomalacia: When the xerophthalmia persists for a long time, it progresses to keratomalacia (softening of the cornea).

  • Other manifestations: General impairment of immunity, keratinization of skin (Phrynoderma/toad skin).

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 2-year history of widespread musculoskeletal pain. She reports persistent fatigue, sleep disturbances, and cognitive difficulties often referred to as "fibro fog." Her pain is described as a constant dull ache, present for more than three months, affecting multiple areas of the body. Physical examination reveals tenderness at multiple specific sites but no joint swelling or signs of inflammation. Extensive laboratory workup, including inflammatory markers and thyroid function tests, is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fibromyalgia

  • This patient's symptoms of widespread pain, fatigue, sleep disturbances, cognitive difficulties, and tenderness at multiple specific sites, in the absence of any objective inflammatory or biochemical abnormalities, are characteristic of fibromyalgia.
  • Fibromyalgia is often a diagnosis of exclusion and is characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues.

Other options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid Arthritis. Typically presents with joint pain and swelling with characteristic patterns of joint involvement and is often associated with positive inflammatory markers, which are not described in this case.

 

Option C. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). A systemic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organ systems and often presents with a wide range of symptoms, including arthritis, skin rashes, and kidney involvement. Laboratory findings in SLE may include specific autoantibodies, which are not mentioned here.

 

Option D. Polymyalgia Rheumatica. Generally, affects older adults (above 50 years) and is characterized by muscle pain and stiffness in the neck, shoulders, and hips, with elevated inflammatory markers such as ESR and CRP, which are not evident in this patient.

choices.text: Minimal change disease

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Minimal change disease

  • Effacement of the podocyte foot processes is characteristically seen in minimal change disease (MCD), which is also called lipoid nephrosis.
  • On light microscopy, characteristic feature is no apparent abnormality in the glomeruli except for slight increase in the mesangial matrix at the most.

 

 

 

  • By electron microscopy, the most characteristic feature of the disease is identified which is diffuse flattening of foot processes of the visceral epithelial cells (podocytes) and, hence, the name foot process disease or podocytopathy.
  • In contrast to other types of GN, no deposits are visible, and the GBM is normal. No complement or immunoglobulin deposits are detected using immunofluorescence microscopy (nil deposit disease).
  • It's also seen in other diseases like membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. These diseases are also known as podocytopathies because they affect podocytes.

choices.text: Factor VIIIa → Factor IXa
Factor Xa → Factor XIa
Factor XIIa → Factor VIIa
Factor XIa → Factor IXa

questions.text: A patient with a severe clotting disorder presents with prolonged bleeding following minor trauma. Laboratory investigations reveal deficiencies in multiple clotting factors. Among these factors, which of the following pairs correctly represents two consecutive activated clotting factors within the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Factor XIa → Factor IXa

 

Explanation:

 

Option A (Factor VIIIa → Factor IXa): Incorrect. Factor VIIIa is an activator of Factor IX, but Factor IXa does not follow Factor VIIIa in the cascade; rather, it is the other way around.

 

Option B (Factor Xa → Factor XIa): Incorrect. Factor Xa is downstream of Factor XIa in the coagulation cascade. Factor XIa activates Factor IX, which ultimately leads to the activation of Factor X.

 

Option C (Factor XIIa → Factor VIIa): Incorrect. Factor XIIa is part of the intrinsic pathway, while Factor VIIa is part of the extrinsic pathway. They do not directly follow each other in the coagulation cascade.

 

Option D (Factor XIa → Factor IXa): Correct. In the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, Factor XIa activates Factor IX to Factor IXa. Factor IXa then forms a complex with Factor VIIIa to activate Factor X to Factor Xa, which is a critical step in the pathway leading to thrombin formation and fibrin clot.

questions.text: Patients undergoing treatment for colorectal cancer have developed symptoms such as tingling, numbness, pain, and erythema on the palms and soles of their feet as shown in the figure below. Which of the following chemotherapy drugs could be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Capecitabine

  • Capecitabine is a chemotherapy drug commonly used to treat colorectal cancer.
  • It is a prodrug that is converted to 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) in the body.
  • One of the known side effects of capecitabine is hand-foot syndrome, which can present as tingling, numbness, pain, and erythema on the palms and soles of the feet.
  • This is thought to be due to the accumulation of the drug in the skin and the subsequent inflammation and damage to the small blood vessels in the affected areas.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female comes to ENT OPD and presents with tinnitus, dizziness and h/o progressive deafness. Differential diagnosis includes all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Histiocytosis-X

  • In the case of a 56-year-old female presenting with tinnitus, dizziness, and a history of progressive deafness, we need to consider various differential diagnoses.

Analysis of given options:

 

Option A. Acoustic Neuroma.

  • Acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, is a benign tumor that arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibulocochlear nerve.
  • It typically presents with unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance disturbances, making it a relevant diagnosis for these symptoms.

 

Option B. Endolymphatic Hydrops.

  • Endolymphatic hydrops is a condition commonly associated with Ménière's disease, characterized by an abnormal accumulation of endolymphatic fluid in the inner ear.
  • It can cause episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and tinnitus.
  • This condition matches the patient's symptoms and should be considered in the differential diagnosis.

 

Option C. Meningioma.

  • Meningiomas are benign tumors arising from the meninges, the membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord.
  • While they can cause neurological symptoms, including hearing loss and tinnitus if they affect certain areas of the brain, they are less commonly associated with these symptoms compared to acoustic neuromas.
  • However, they cannot be ruled out entirely based on the presented symptoms.

Option D. Histiocytosis-X (Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis).

  • Histiocytosis-X, now more commonly known as Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH), is a rare disorder characterized by an abnormal proliferation of Langerhans cells.
  • LCH can affect various organs, including the bones and skin, but involvement of the auditory system in the manner described (progressive deafness, tinnitus, and dizziness) is uncommon.
  • Given the patient's specific symptoms, LCH is less likely to be the cause compared to the other conditions listed.

Based on this analysis, the least likely diagnosis among the options given, considering the specific presentation of the patient, is D. Histiocytosis-X (Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis).

 

Educational Objective:

  • Evaluate and differentiate various conditions such as acoustic neuroma, endolymphatic hydrops, meningioma, and Langerhans cell histiocytosis in the context of a patient presenting with tinnitus, dizziness, and progressive deafness.

questions.text: After birth, the intra-abdominal remnants of the umbilical vein become which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ligamentum teres

  • Oxygenated blood enters the fetus through: Umbilical Vein
    • Functional closure occurs after closure of umbilical artery.
    • It forms the ligamentum teres.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ligamentum venosum is formed from the ductus venosus.

 

Option C. Ligamentum vascularum. There is no such thing as ligamentum vascularum.

 

Option D. Umbilical ligaments. The medial umbilical ligaments are the obliterated part of the umbilical artery.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Oxygenated blood enters the fetus through: Umbilical Vein
    • Functional closure occurs after closure of umbilical artery.
    • Forms the ligamentum teres 
  • Deoxygenated Blood exits the fetus through Umbilical arteries.
    • Functional closure of umbilical arteries: immediately after birth
    • Anatomical closure: 2-3months
    • Proximal part form the superior vesical arteries.
    • Distal part form the medial umbilical ligaments.
  • Ductus venosus: Shunts blood from umbilical vein to IVC
    • Functional closure: 10-96h after birth
    • Anatomic closure: 3-7 days
    • Forms the ligamentum venosum
  • Ductus arteriosus: Shunts blood from Pulmonary artery to Aorta
    • Functional closure: 12-24 h
    • Anatomic closure: 2-3 weeks
  • Foramen ovale:
    • Functional closure: soon after birth
    • Anatomical closure: at 1 year

 

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no. 343

choices.text: Central retinal vein occlusion

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents after 3 days of cataract surgery with history of pain and decrease in vision after an initial improvement. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Endophthalmitis

  • Endophthalmitis is a severe infection that can occur after intraocular surgery, such as cataract surgery. It is characterized by inflammation and infection within the interior structures of the eye.
  • Symptoms of endophthalmitis can include pain, redness, decreased vision, and sometimes discharge from the eye.
  • It typically presents a few days to a week after surgery, as described in the case.
  • Endophthalmitis is considered a medical emergency because it can lead to significant vision loss if not promptly treated with intravitreal antibiotics and sometimes vitrectomy (surgical removal of the vitreous gel).

Other options:

 

Option B. After cataract.

  • "After cataract" is not a recognized medical condition.
  • Patients may experience a secondary clouding of the posterior lens capsule after cataract surgery, which is called posterior capsule opacification.
  • However, this condition does not typically cause pain and severe vision loss like endophthalmitis.

Option C. Central retinal vein occlusion.

  • Central retinal vein occlusion is a vascular obstruction condition that affects the blood supply to the retina.
  • It can cause sudden vision loss, but it is not typically associated with pain and does not occur immediately after cataract surgery.

Option D. Retinal detachment.

  • Retinal detachment involves the separation of the retina from the underlying tissue.
  • It can cause symptoms such as floaters, flashes of light, and a curtain-like shadow in the visual field.
  • While retinal detachment is a serious condition, it does not usually present immediately after cataract surgery and is not typically associated with pain as the primary symptom.

choices.text: It binds to the intracellular face of Na+ K+ ATPase enzyme.
There is rise in intracellular Na+
It has positive ionotropic action.
Digitalis action is independent of cardiac innervation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the mechanism of action of digitalis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It binds to the intracellular face of Na+ K+ ATPase enzyme.

 

DIGITALIS MECHANISM OF ACTION

  • Digitalis increases the force of contraction by a direct action independent of the innervation.
  • It binds to the extracellular face of the Na+ K+ ATPase and inhibits the enzyme causing rise in the intracellular levels of Na+.
  • The raised Na+ in turn inhibits the Na+ Ca2+ exchanger and causes rise in intracellular Ca2+.
  • This raised intracellular Ca2+ is responsible for the positive ionotropic effect.
  • Thus, digitalis increases the cardiac contractility and force of contraction.

choices.text: There is at least one episode of mania.
The duration criterion for diagnosis is 2 years.
There is at least one episode of depression.
There is at least one episode of hypomania.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with concerns about his fluctuating mood over the last two and a half years. He describes periods of elevated mood, increased goal-directed activity, and heightened creativity that last for a few days, but these episodes are not severe enough to cause significant impairment in his social or work life. He also experiences several days of low mood, fatigue, and disinterest in activities, yet these symptoms do not meet the full criteria for a major depressive episode. He has never experienced a full manic or major depressive episode. Which of the following statements is correct about the likely diagnosis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The duration criterion for diagnosis is 2 years.

  • The correct diagnosis in this case is cyclothymic disorder.
  • The key feature of cyclothymic disorder is a chronic, fluctuating mood disturbance involving numerous periods of hypomanic and depressive symptoms over at least a 2-year period in adults (1 year in children and adolescents).
  • These symptoms do not meet the criteria for a manic episode or a major depressive episode.

Other Options:

 

Option A. This is incorrect because the patient does not have a history of a full manic episode, which would be suggestive of bipolar I disorder.

 

Option C. This is incorrect because, although the patient experiences symptoms of depression, he does not have episodes that meet the full criteria for a major depressive episode.

 

Option D. This option is a distractor. While the patient does experience episodes of hypomania, the key to the diagnosis of cyclothymia is the chronic nature and duration of the symptoms, which is addressed in option B.

 

Educational Objective:

  • The diagnosis of cyclothymic disorder requires at least a 2-year period of fluctuating hypomanic and depressive symptoms that do not meet the criteria for a manic episode or a major depressive episode.

questions.text: A patient on chemotherapy was administered an antiemetic to control nausea. Subsequently, the patient developed symptoms including acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following antiemetic medications is most likely to have caused these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metoclopramide

  • Metoclopramide is an antiemetic and a prokinetic drug that acts by blocking the D2 receptors.
  • It can cross the Blood brain barrier, thereby leading to D2 receptor blockade in the brain resulting in extrapyramidal symptoms like acute dystonia, abnormal movements and drug induced Parkinsonism.
  • Central anticholinergic drugs like Benzhexol are used for treatment of these symptoms. They work by restoring the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the striatum.

Explanation of Other Options:

 

Option A. Ondansetron. It is a 5-HT receptor antagonist and is considered as drug of choice for nausea and vomiting caused by cancer chemotherapy. It is generally well-tolerated and not known to cause extrapyramidal symptoms like dystonia or bradykinesia.

 

Option C. Meclizine. It is an antihistaminic drug that is commonly used for motion sickness and vertigo. It is not associated with extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Scopolamine. It is an anticholinergic agent used for motion sickness. It can cause dry mouth, blurred vision, and urinary retention, but is not associated with extrapyramidal side effects like dystonia or bradykinesia.

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. -2 microglobulin

 

  • -2 microglobulin is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma.

 

Elevated levels reflect:

 

  • Tumor burden
  • Renal dysfunction
  • Higher levels Poor prognosis
  • Serum albumin
    • Used in combination with -2 microglobulin in the ISS.

 

Lower albumin Worse prognosis

 

  • Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm commonly associated with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and acquired immune abnormalities.

  • CRAB criteria for MM:

    • Hypercalcemia: serum calcium >11mg/dl

    • Renal Insufficiency: serum creatinine >2 mg/dl or creatinine clearance <40 ml/min

    • Anemia: Hb <10 g/dl

    • Lytic bone lesions

 

 

Poor prognostic factors for multiple myeloma:

 

  • Serum Beta 2-microglobulin: It is the single most powerful predictor

  • Deletion of 17pITP53 sequences and the translocations t (14;16) and t(14;20)

  • Polyclonal serum Immunoglobulins

  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase

  • High C-reactive protein

  • Increased plasma cell proliferative activity

  • High degree of bone marrow replacement

  • Presence of plasmablastic morphology

  • Elevated serum soluble receptor for IL6

choices.text: S. aureus enterotoxin
C. difficile toxins
C. perfringens toxins

questions.text: A 70-year-old male had surgery for a ruptured sigmoid colon diverticulum with an abscess. A repair was done and the abscess was drained. He was treated with IV Gentamicin & Ampicillin. 10 days later, he had multiple episodes of diarrhea, his stool was positive for occult blood and the presence of polymorphonuclear cells. On sigmoidoscopy the mucosa is erythematous and inflamed and there were many raised white to yellowish plaques. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C. difficile toxins

  • Multiple episodes of diarrhea, his stool was positive for occult blood and the presence of polymorphonuclear cells after antibiotic use points towards Antibiotic associated colitis or Pseudomembrane colitis caused by Clostridium difficile.
  • C. difficile produces 2 toxins:
    1. enterotoxin
    2. cytotoxin
  • Toxin A is responsible for diarrhea and toxin B is capable of producing cytopathogenic effects in several tissue culture cell lines.

Other options:

 

Option A. S. aureus enterotoxin causes food poisoning in humans.

 

Option C. C. perfringens. Alpha toxin Produced by C. perfringens, it has both phospholipase c and sphingomyelinase activities and it is the principle virulence factor. Gamma toxin have minor lethal actions. Beta toxin have lethal and necrotising properties. Delta toxin is lethal and haemolytic.

 

Option D. Enterohemorrhagic E. coli can cause hemorrhagic colitis and life threatening complications such as hemolytic uremic syndrome.

 

 

Ref: CP Baveja, V. Baveja, 7th edition, page no. 614

choices.text: Alpha1 antitrypsin deficiency is important in its pathogenesis
Reid index may be increased
Airway remodeling may be seen

questions.text: A 40-year-old male complains of chronic cough with expectoration of foul smelling sputum on and off since 6 months. He also has moderate dyspnea. The pathology of his lung is represented alongside. What statement best describes his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Common in lower lobes

 

The pulmonary pathology shown is bronchiectasis wherein dilated, thickened bronchioles can be followed up to the periphery of the lung. It is common in lower lobes due to pooling of secretions. Especially affects posterior basal segments of lower lobes due to gravity-dependent drainage and chronic infection/inflammation.

 

If secondary to aspiration, CF, or post-tubercular damage, lower lobe involvement is typical. 

 

The main causes of bronchiectasis are obstruction and necrotizing infections. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha1 antitrypsin deficiency is important in its pathogenesis: Alpha 1 anti-trypsin is implicated in pathogenesis of emphysema. Seen in panacinar emphysema, especially involving lower lobes.

 

  • AAT deficiency leads to destruction of alveolar walls due to unchecked neutrophil elastase.
  • Not a cause of bronchiectasis, although both can coexist in severe lung disease.

 

Option B. Reid index may be increased: Reid index is increased in chronic bronchitis due to mucus gland hyperplasia.

 

  • Reid index = thickness of mucous gland layer / total thickness of bronchial wall.
  • Not a characteristic of bronchiectasis.

 

Option C. Airway remodeling may be seen: Airway remodelling occurs in bronchial asthma due to repeated injury and repair.

 

  • Involves thickened basement membrane, smooth muscle hypertrophy, goblet cell metaplasia.
  • Not a defining feature of bronchiectasis, which is more about permanent dilation and destruction of bronchi due to chronic inflammation.

1-i, 2-ii, 3-iii, 4-iv

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-iii, 2-ii, 3-iv, 4-i

questions.text: A 55-year-old man came with chief complaints of fever characterised by abrupt onset of fever, maculopapular rash over the chest and upper limbs, severe frontal headaches, muscle and joint pains. Serological test was done for dengue infection NS1 antigen and the result is displayed. Observe the result and answer the test:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Immunochromatographic assay

  • It is based on lateral flow technique.
  • The test system comprises of a nitrocellulose membrane (NCM) and absorbent pad.
  • The NCM is coated at two places in form of lines-a test line coated with specific monoclonal Ab against the target antigen and control line coated with anti-species immunoglobulin.

Other options:

 

Option A. ELISA test. This test is usually done in a microtiter plate and it uses enzyme substrate system for detection.

 

Option C. Western blot. Western blot detects the specific protein in a sample targeted against different antigens of same microbe.

 

Option D. PCR. Its molecular method in detection of microorganisms, it amplifies single or multiple copies of DNA to generate million copies of DNA.
